locations.name: Mission Dolores
locations.tagline: The oldest building in San Francisco holds the city's deepest contradictions.

eras.label: Ohlone Homeland
eras.headline: Mannahatta of the West
eras.description: The Ramaytush Ohlone people had lived on this peninsula for at least 10,000 years before European contact. The Mission Valley was a wetland fed by Mission Creek, teeming with tule elk, grizzly bear, and more bird species than exist in the entire state today. The Yelamu band maintained several villages within what is now San Francisco, moving seasonally between the bay shore and inland oak groves. Their world was not wilderness — it was a managed, abundant landscape that sustained thousands of people across generations.

key_events.event: First confirmed human habitation of the San Francisco peninsula
Yelamu village of Chutchui established near present-day Mission Dolores
Juan Cabrillo sails past the Golden Gate without entering — the bay remains unknown to Europeans for another 227 years
Gaspar de Portola becomes the first European to sight San Francisco Bay, from the hills above

eras.landscape: Mission Valley held a seasonal lagoon fed by springs and Mission Creek. The hills were covered in coastal scrub and wind-bent oak. Coyote brush, lupine, and bunch grasses covered the slopes. The air smelled of salt marsh and bay laurel. Silence, except for birds and wind.
sources: Randall Milliken, A Time of Little Choice (1995)
Peter Fimrite, Ohlone cultural research, SF Chronicle
Alan Leventhal, San Jose State archaeological surveys

eras.label: Spanish Mission
eras.headline: The Founding Violence
eras.description: Mission San Francisco de Asis was established on June 29, 1776 — five days before the American Declaration of Independence was signed on the other side of the continent. The Spanish colonial project was explicit: convert the Ohlone to Christianity, put them to work building the mission, and erase the culture that had sustained the peninsula for millennia. The Yelamu population collapsed catastrophically. Thousands died of introduced disease, overwork, and despair within decades of the mission's founding. The adobe church that still stands — the oldest intact building in San Francisco — was built with Ohlone labor.

key_events.event: Mission Dolores founded by Father Francisco Palou, one of 21 California missions
Current adobe church completed using Ohlone forced labor — it still stands today
Ohlone population at the mission reaches its lowest recorded point due to epidemic disease
Mexico wins independence from Spain — California becomes Mexican territory

eras.landscape: The mission complex was a self-contained agricultural world — the adobe church, a granary, workshops, and housing surrounded by fields of wheat, cattle ranches stretching south, and an aqueduct channeling water from the springs. The lagoon still existed to the east, attracting abundant waterfowl. Wooden cross on a hill visible for miles.
sources: Msgr. Francis Weber, The Mission in the Valley (1979)

eras.label: Gold Rush
eras.headline: The First Tech Boom
eras.description: The Gold Rush transformed San Francisco from a settlement of 800 people to a city of 25,000 in under eighteen months. The Mission District in this period was the recreational periphery of the boomtown — horse racing on Mission Road, saloons, gambling houses, and the pleasure gardens that catered to men who had crossed a continent or an ocean to get rich. The mission church sat at the center of this chaos, its Ohlone congregation long since scattered or dead, now serving a Spanish-speaking community amid the Anglo flood.

key_events.event: Gold discovered at Sutter's Mill — news reaches San Francisco in May, the rush begins
Population explodes from 800 to 25,000. Tent cities cover the hills.
California admitted to the Union as the 31st state
Mission Plank Road constructed — the first paved road in San Francisco, running from downtown to the mission

eras.landscape: The valley between the mission and downtown was still largely open, crossed by a plank road and dotted with roadhouses and saloons. The lagoon had been partially drained. Sand dunes dominated the western neighborhoods. The mission church stood in relative quiet compared to the chaos of the waterfront — a remnant of a different civilization, already being absorbed into the American city growing around it.
sources: Kevin Starr, Americans and the California Dream (1973)

eras.label: After the Fire
eras.headline: The City That Refused to Die
eras.description: At 5:12 AM on April 18, 1906, a rupture along the San Andreas Fault shook San Francisco for 45 seconds. The earthquake was devastating, but the fire that followed was apocalyptic. For three days, the city burned. 28,000 buildings were destroyed. Between 3,000 and 6,000 people died. The Mission District was one of the few areas that survived relatively intact — its wide streets and lower building density allowed firebreaks to hold. Refugees from the burning city poured into Dolores Park, which had been a Jewish cemetery until 1894.

key_events.event: Earthquake strikes at 5:12 AM. The rupture is felt from Oregon to Los Angeles.
Fires burn for three days, destroying 490 city blocks
Dolores Park becomes a refugee camp for 1,600 displaced residents
The city rebuilds at extraordinary speed — the Mission fills with Victorian housing for displaced residents

eras.landscape: The contrast was stark: looking north from the mission toward downtown was a field of ash and chimney stacks. The Mission itself was crowded with tents and improvised structures housing the displaced. Dolores Street's palm trees stood over a tent city. Within three years, the Victorian row houses that now define the Mission's streetscape had been built, almost all at once, as the city reconstructed itself.
sources: Simon Winchester, A Crack in the Edge of the World (2005)
Philip Fradkin, The Great Earthquake and Firestorms of 1906 (2005)

eras.label: Wartime Mission
eras.headline: The Working Neighborhood
eras.description: By 1945 the Mission was one of San Francisco's densest working-class neighborhoods — Irish, Italian, German, and a growing Latino population that had been arriving since the 1910s. The war had changed everything. The shipyards of the Bay Area were running 24 hours a day. Women were working in factories. The Mission's flat terrain and grid of transit lines made it a natural hub for workers moving between home and the waterfront industries. 24th Street was packed with grocers, butchers, and bars serving the neighborhood's ethnic mix.

key_events.event: US enters WWII after Pearl Harbor. Bay Area shipyards shift to full war production.
Japanese-American residents of the Mission forcibly relocated to internment camps
V-J Day celebrations erupt on Mission Street. The war is over.
Latino population of the Mission reaches 20% — the demographic shift that will define the neighborhood is underway

eras.landscape: Dense Victorian housing lining every block. Corner groceries and bars every few hundred feet. The streetcar running up Mission Street. Neon signs and hand-painted storefronts. Dolores Park used as a drill ground by the National Guard. The smell of bakeries, laundries, and the ever-present fog rolling in from the ocean.
sources: Robert O'Brien, This is San Francisco (1948)
SF Public Library History Center archives
Jerry Garcia's childhood recollections of the Mission (various interviews)

eras.label: Counterculture
eras.headline: Two Cities, One Street
eras.description: While the Haight-Ashbury drew the national media attention during the Summer of Love, the Mission was quietly becoming the cultural capital of Latino San Francisco. The neighborhood that had absorbed Irish and Italian immigrants for decades was now predominantly Mexican and Central American. Murals were beginning to appear on walls. The Mission Cultural Center was years away, but the energy that would produce it was already present on 24th Street. Two blocks away, hippies were selling flowers. The Mission paid them little attention.

key_events.event: The Mission rebels against urban renewal plans that would have demolished the neighborhood
Summer of Love in adjacent Haight-Ashbury brings 100,000 young people to San Francisco
Mission Coalition Organization founded — one of the most effective community organizing efforts in SF history
First major Mission murals appear, beginning a public art tradition that continues today

eras.landscape: Mission Street was a commercial corridor in transition — Latino businesses replacing the Irish establishments, Spanish-language signs appearing alongside English ones. Dolores Park was overgrown and underused. The Victorian housing stock was aging but intact. On certain blocks, you could walk from a taqueria to a head shop to a Catholic church in fifty steps.
sources: Roberto Hernandez, The Mission: A Neighborhood History

eras.label: Dot-com Wave
eras.headline: The First Displacement
eras.description: The first dot-com boom hit the Mission like a wave hitting a seawall. Between 1997 and 2001, the neighborhood that had been Latino working-class for thirty years was convulsed by evictions, rising rents, and the arrival of tech workers who had discovered that the Mission's Victorian housing and restaurant density made it an appealing place to live. The Ellis Act — a state law allowing landlords to evict tenants to take buildings off the rental market — was used at record rates. Community organizations fought back with protests and ballot measures, some successful, most not.

key_events.event: South of Market begins its transformation from industrial to tech office space
Mission rents double. Ellis Act evictions reach record levels.
Anti-gentrification protests shut down dot-com parties in the Mission
Dot-com bust. Some pressure temporarily relieved. The Mission exhales.

eras.landscape: Valencia Street transformed fastest — used bookstores and car repair shops becoming bars and restaurants serving the new residents. The murals remained but their context changed. Luxury lofts appeared on former industrial lots. The Google shuttle stops that would define the next wave didn't exist yet — but the pattern was established.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: Holding On
eras.description: The Mission in 2025 is a neighborhood that has been through two tech booms and is still, improbably, recognizably itself. The displacement has been real and ongoing — the Latino population that was 60% in 1990 is now closer to 40%. But the murals are still there, expanded and maintained. 24th Street remains a Latino commercial corridor. Mission Dolores — the 1791 adobe church — still holds services. The community organizations that fought the first wave are still operating, more experienced now, more legally sophisticated.
eras.landscape: Valencia Street is unrecognizable to anyone who knew it in 1990. Mission Street remains a working-class corridor. The contrast between the two, separated by one block, is the Mission's defining spatial fact in 2025. Dolores Park on a sunny weekend is a cross-section of the city that nowhere else achieves.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: Two Missions
eras.description: In the managed adaptation scenario, the Mission has become one of the city's most climate-resilient neighborhoods — its flat terrain and grid of parks making it a natural cooling corridor as temperatures rise. Mission Creek, buried for a century, has been partially daylighted as a bioswale running through the neighborhood. In the displacement scenario, the final wave of gentrification has hollowed the neighborhood entirely — the murals preserved as tourist attractions, the community that made them scattered across the East Bay.

future_scenarios.label: Adaptation
future_scenarios.description: Mission Creek returns to daylight as a cooling corridor. The neighborhood's flat terrain and park grid make it a model climate-resilient district. Community land trusts have stabilized the remaining Latino institutions.

future_scenarios.label: Displacement
future_scenarios.description: The murals remain, preserved and curated. The community that painted them is gone. The Mission is a museum of a neighborhood that used to exist, expensive and quiet.

locations.name: The Embarcadero
locations.tagline: For 150 years this waterfront was the mouth of American commerce. Then a freeway buried it. Then the earthquake set it free.

eras.label: Ohlone Shore
eras.headline: The Living Shore
eras.description: The eastern shore of the San Francisco peninsula was a dynamic tidal landscape — mudflats, salt marsh, and shellmound beaches extending into the bay. The Yelamu Ohlone maintained shellmound villages along this shore, the middens of oyster and mussel shells accumulating over millennia into structures large enough to be visible landmarks. The bay was cold, clear, and impossibly rich. Salmon runs so thick they could be scooped by hand. Shorebirds in numbers that blocked the sky.

key_events.event: Shellmound villages established along the eastern shore
Portola expedition reaches the bay — the first European sighting

eras.landscape: Uninterrupted tidal marsh from the base of the hills to the water's edge. The bay's western shoreline was not a sharp line but a gradient — marsh grass, mudflat, and open water blending into each other. Grizzly bears fished the salmon runs alongside the Ohlone.
sources: SF Estuary Institute historical ecology research

eras.label: Spanish Harbor
eras.headline: The Anchorage
eras.description: When the Spanish established the Presidio in 1776, the Embarcadero waterfront was the natural harbor for the new settlement. Ships anchored in the protected cove. The land was still wild — no wharves, no piers, just a rocky shoreline where boats pulled up on the sand.

key_events.event: Spanish establish the Presidio — ships anchor along the eastern shore
Yerba Buena settlement forms near the waterfront

eras.landscape: A rocky shoreline with kelp and driftwood. Spanish ships at anchor. The cove protected from the ocean wind by the hills of the peninsula. Seals on the rocks.
sources: Barbara Berglund, Making San Francisco American (2007)

eras.label: Gold Rush Port
eras.headline: The Forest of Masts
eras.description: At the height of the Gold Rush, so many ships entered San Francisco Bay and were abandoned by crews who ran for the gold fields that the cove was a forest of masts. Hundreds of ships were beached and converted to warehouses, hotels, and saloons — the city's first buildings were repurposed hulls. The shoreline was pushed outward by fill dumped into the cove: rubble, ships, debris, and soil. The streets of the Financial District east of Montgomery are built on this fill today.

key_events.event: First ships arrive bearing gold seekers — the bay transforms overnight
Over 700 ships abandoned in Yerba Buena Cove as crews desert for the gold fields
Systematic landfill begins extending the shoreline eastward

eras.landscape: Yerba Buena Cove packed with masts. The original shoreline — now Montgomery Street — already buried under fill. Canvas and wood buildings clinging to the hillsides above. The smell of salt water, lumber, canvas, and the ever-present mud.

eras.label: After the Fire
eras.headline: Ground Zero
eras.description: The earthquake and fire of 1906 burned to the waterfront. The Ferry Building, completed in 1898, survived — its thick masonry construction and the firebreak of the Embarcadero roadway protecting it. It became the primary relief station for the disaster, the point where food and aid entered the devastated city. 200,000 people were left homeless. The waterfront was the city's lifeline.

key_events.event: Ferry Building completed — at the time the second busiest transit terminal in the world
Earthquake and fire. The Ferry Building survives and becomes the city's relief hub.
Ferry traffic reaches its peak — 50,000 passengers per day

eras.landscape: The Ferry Building tower visible from miles away, a reference point for a devastated city. The Embarcadero roadway packed with relief wagons and refugees. The bay itself unaffected — the same cold water it had always been, indifferent to human catastrophe.
sources: Ferry Building historical records, Port of San Francisco

eras.label: The Industrial Port
eras.headline: The Working Waterfront
eras.description: During WWII the Embarcadero was the industrial heart of the Pacific theater's supply chain. The piers ran continuously. Longshoremen worked in shifts around the clock. The International Longshore and Warehouse Union, led by Harry Bridges, was one of the most powerful labor organizations in the country — a communist-led union that had shut down the entire West Coast in the General Strike of 1934. The waterfront was not a scenic amenity. It was a serious industrial place that smelled of diesel, salt water, and fish.

key_events.event: The Big Strike — West Coast longshoremen shut down all ports for 83 days
War production transforms the waterfront into a military supply operation
Troop ships return through the Golden Gate. The waterfront witnesses the end of the war.

eras.landscape: Piers extending into the bay every hundred feet, each serving a specific cargo or shipping company. The Ferry Building diminished in importance as bridge traffic replaced ferry traffic after 1936. The Embarcadero itself was a working road — trucks, forklifts, longshoremen. Not a place for pedestrians.

eras.label: The Freeway Years
eras.headline: Buried Alive
eras.description: The Embarcadero Freeway opened in 1959 and immediately severed the city from its waterfront. A double-deck elevated highway ran along the Embarcadero, blocking views of the bay and casting the waterfront in permanent shadow. The Ferry Building, which had been the city's front door, became an afterthought behind a wall of concrete. Proposals to extend the freeway further were defeated by a citizen revolt — one of the first successful freeway revolts in American history. But the existing structure stayed for thirty more years.

key_events.event: Embarcadero Freeway opens — immediately controversial
Citizens successfully block the freeway's extension through Golden Gate Park
Loma Prieta earthquake damages the freeway — the city uses it as an opportunity to remove it
Embarcadero Freeway demolished. The waterfront blinks in the light for the first time in thirty years.

eras.landscape: A wall of concrete where the waterfront should have been. The bay visible only in glimpses through the structure's supports. The Ferry Building functioning as a minor produce market behind the freeway, its tower poking above the concrete deck, visible but inaccessible.
sources: Martin Wachs, The freeway revolt and the making of metropolitan America

eras.label: The Restoration
eras.headline: The Waterfront Returns
eras.description: The Ferry Building reopened after a three-year renovation in 2003, transformed from a produce market into a food hall that became the model for urban market renovations across the country. The Embarcadero promenade — the stretch of waterfront that the freeway had blocked for thirty years — became one of the most valued public spaces in San Francisco. The farmer's market that began in 1992 expanded. The waterfront that the 19th century had industrialized, the 20th century had buried under concrete, was returning to public life.

key_events.event: Freeway demolished after Loma Prieta damage — the waterfront reopens
Ferry Plaza Farmers Market established
Renovated Ferry Building reopens as a food market

eras.landscape: The Ferry Building tower reflected in the bay at high tide. The promenade filled with cyclists, pedestrians, and the farmer's market on weekends. The bay visible again from the city. The piers converted to offices, restaurants, and event spaces. A leisure landscape where an industrial one had been.
sources: SPUR, San Francisco waterfront planning history
Port of San Francisco redevelopment records

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The City's Living Room
eras.description: The Embarcadero in 2025 is what urban planners call a great public space — activated at all hours, used by all demographics, connecting transit to waterfront to commerce. The Ferry Building farmers market on Saturday mornings is one of the few places in San Francisco where you genuinely encounter the full range of the city. The bay is cleaner than it has been in a century. Sea level rise planning is underway — the waterfront that was rebuilt once after a freeway may need to be rebuilt again as the water rises.
eras.landscape: The Ferry Building tower framing the bay view from Market Street. The Embarcadero streetcar running along the waterfront. Alcatraz visible on clear days. The Bay Bridge lit at night with Leo Villareal's light installation, 25,000 LEDs programmed in perpetual non-repeating sequence.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The Rising Water
eras.description: Sea level projections for San Francisco Bay range from 1 to 3 feet by 2075 under different emissions scenarios. The Embarcadero, built on fill that liquefies in earthquakes and sits barely above current sea level, faces fundamental questions about its future.

future_scenarios.label: The Seawall
future_scenarios.description: A comprehensive seawall completed by 2055 protects the waterfront. The Embarcadero continues as a public space, elevated slightly, with new wetland habitat created on the bay side of the wall as both ecological restoration and wave attenuation.

future_scenarios.label: Managed Retreat
future_scenarios.description: Rather than holding the current shoreline, the city allows the bay to reclaim the fill areas and rebuilds the waterfront further inland. The Ferry Building, if it survives, stands on a new shoreline. The blocks east of it return to tidal marsh.

locations.name: Montgomery Street
locations.tagline: Every California economic cycle — gold, railroad, banking, tech — has left its sediment here.

eras.label: The Shore
eras.headline: Before the Fill
eras.description: Montgomery Street today runs along what was the original eastern shoreline of Yerba Buena Cove. Everything east of it is fill — rubble, ships, and soil dumped into the bay beginning in 1851. The land the Financial District stands on did not exist 175 years ago. It was cold bay water.

key_events.event: Yerba Buena Cove's western shore sits at what is now Montgomery Street
Spanish establish the Presidio and Mission — the cove remains undeveloped

eras.landscape: Open bay water where the Financial District now stands. The hills of the peninsula rising from the original shoreline. Yerba Buena island visible in the middle distance. Silence except for wind and seabirds.

eras.label: The Cove
eras.headline: Yerba Buena Cove
eras.description: The area that would become the Financial District was underwater in 1776 — part of Yerba Buena Cove, a shallow inlet that would later be filled in to create downtown San Francisco. The Spanish knew the cove as a sheltered anchorage, but built nothing here.

key_events.event: Yerba Buena Cove — a shallow inlet in the bay
First settlement near the cove

eras.landscape: Shallow water at high tide, mudflats at low. The cove surrounded by sand hills. Ships entering the bay would see this protected water and anchor here.
sources: Barbara Berglund, Making San Francisco American (2007)

eras.label: Gold Rush Banks
eras.headline: The First Financial District
eras.description: The Gold Rush created the Financial District almost overnight. The banks, assay offices, and counting houses that processed the gold coming down from the Sierra Nevada concentrated along Montgomery Street — which sat at the original shoreline, at the base of the hills, where the gold-bearing ships docked. By 1852, Montgomery Street had more banks per block than any street in America.

key_events.event: Gold discovered — financial infrastructure needed immediately
First banks established on Montgomery Street
San Francisco becomes the financial capital of the American West

eras.landscape: Canvas and wood buildings quickly replaced by brick as the stakes became clear. Montgomery Street muddy in winter, dusty in summer, packed with men in the universal uniform of the Gold Rush — rough wool, boots, and a hat against the wind.
sources: Bancroft Library Gold Rush financial records

eras.label: After the Fire
eras.headline: Ruins and Resolve
eras.description: The Financial District burned completely in 1906. The great banking houses, the office towers, the counting houses — all of it reduced to facades and rubble. Remarkably, the vaults held. Wells Fargo recovered its gold. The banks reopened within weeks, operating from the ruins or from tents. The reconstruction of the Financial District was the fastest large-scale urban rebuilding in American history — within three years, a new city of reinforced concrete and steel had risen from the ash.

key_events.event: Earthquake and fire destroy the Financial District completely
Bank of Italy (later Bank of America) reopens from a plank across two barrels on the waterfront
Rebuilt Financial District reopens — denser and taller than before

eras.landscape: Photographs from May 1906 show block after block of standing facades with nothing behind them — the iron and brick fronts held while the interiors burned. By 1907 the sound of construction was constant. The new buildings were taller, built of reinforced concrete, built to last.

eras.label: Postwar Capital
eras.headline: The Command Center
eras.description: In 1945 the Financial District was the financial capital of the American West — and given Europe's devastation and the Pacific's distance, arguably of much of the world. The Bank of America, headquartered here, was the largest bank in the world. The transpacific trade routes all ran through San Francisco. The men (almost entirely men) who worked in the Financial District wore suits and hats and walked to lunch at the same restaurants every day.

key_events.event: Bank of America Tower completed — for a time the tallest building west of the Mississippi
V-J Day. San Francisco is the last American port the Pacific fleet left from and the first it returns to.

eras.landscape: Low-rise masonry towers from the post-earthquake rebuild, topped by a few taller buildings from the 1920s and 30s. The streets were narrow and dark, the buildings close. A pedestrian city — parking was scarce, most workers came by streetcar.
sources: Marquis James, Biography of a Bank: The Story of Bank of America (1954)

eras.label: The High-Rise Era
eras.headline: Going Vertical
eras.description: The 1960s brought the first wave of high-rise construction to the Financial District, transforming the low-rise masonry skyline of the post-earthquake rebuild into the tower canyon visible today. The Transamerica Pyramid was proposed in 1969 and completed in 1972 — initially controversial enough to generate formal protests. The Bank of America Building (now 555 California) was completed in 1969 and remained the tallest building in San Francisco for decades.

key_events.event: Citizens form San Francisco Planning and Urban Research Association to fight unchecked development
Bank of America Building completed at 52 stories
Transamerica Pyramid completed — the last major tower approved before height limits imposed

eras.landscape: A city in vertical transition — the low masonry buildings of the 1906 rebuild being shadowed and replaced by glass and steel towers. Construction cranes visible from every angle. The streets narrower in feel as the buildings grew taller.
sources: Allan Temko, No Way to Build a Ballpark (1993)

eras.label: Dot-com Peak
eras.headline: The Second Gold Rush
eras.description: By 2000 the Financial District and adjacent South of Market had become the center of the first dot-com boom. Office space was impossible to find. Foosball tables appeared in converted warehouses. The Nasdaq hit 5,000. Every financial institution in the district was making loans to companies with no revenue and no path to profit. When it collapsed in 2001, the vacancy rate in San Francisco office space went from near-zero to 20% in eighteen months.

key_events.event: Netscape IPO — the dot-com era begins in earnest
Nasdaq peaks at 5,049. SF office vacancy near zero.
Crash. Office vacancy reaches 20%. The bust is as fast as the boom.

eras.landscape: The Financial District towers now surrounded by SoMa startups in converted warehouses. Bike messengers, catered lunches on sidewalks, impossible rents. And then, abruptly: empty offices, for lease signs, the particular silence of a boom gone quiet.
sources: Po Bronson, The Nudist on the Late Shift (1999)
SF Office of Economic Analysis reports

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Hybrid District
eras.description: The Financial District in 2025 is navigating the post-pandemic transformation of office work. Vacancy rates that reached 30% after 2020 have partially recovered but the district's future as a purely office-driven neighborhood is uncertain. The ground floors of towers that once housed banking halls are becoming restaurants, gyms, and retail. The Transamerica Pyramid, sold to German investors, has been renovated. Salesforce Tower dominates the skyline at 1,070 feet.
eras.landscape: Salesforce Tower redefining the skyline. The Salesforce Transit Center — the 'Grand Central of the West' — partially realized, its planned rail connections still unbuilt. A quieter street life than 2019, the morning rush thinned by remote work.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The Reinvented District
eras.description: The Financial District's future is less certain than at any point since 1906. The towers will stand — they were built to last centuries. But what they're used for, and by whom, is an open question.

future_scenarios.label: Mixed City
future_scenarios.description: The tower canyon is converted: upper floors become housing, ground floors become markets and community space. The Financial District becomes a neighborhood where people actually live, for the first time in its history. Density without cars. A vertical city.

future_scenarios.label: AI Campus
future_scenarios.description: The major AI companies have consolidated their physical presence in the Financial District towers. It is an unusually quiet place — most of the economic activity happens in data centers elsewhere. The towers are occupied but not dense with human activity. A company town at urban scale.

locations.name: Chinatown
locations.tagline: The oldest Chinatown in North America. They tried to erase it four times. It's still here.

eras.label: The Hill
eras.headline: Nob Hill Before the Nobs
eras.description: The land that would become Chinatown sits on the eastern slope of Nob Hill, the most prominent of San Francisco's hills. In Ohlone times it was a windswept ridge covered in coastal scrub, used for travel between the bay shore and the peninsula's interior.

key_events.event: Ohlone travel route runs along the ridge that will become Grant Avenue

eras.landscape: A steep hill above the bay shore, swept by ocean wind. Coastal scrub — coyote brush, sticky monkey flower, coffeeberry. Views to the bay in three directions.

eras.label: Spanish Ridge
eras.headline: Between Presidio and Mission
eras.description: In 1776, the hills that would become Chinatown were traversed by the trail between the Presidio and Mission Dolores. The Spanish soldiers crossed this ridge daily. The land was unclaimed, windswept, covered in coastal scrub — unremarkable territory between two posts of empire.

key_events.event: Spanish trail crosses the ridge
Yerba Buena settlement begins to grow nearby

eras.landscape: A steep hillside covered in coastal scrub. The trail from the Presidio winding through. Wind from the bay. The view to the east across the water.
sources: Barbara Berglund, Making San Francisco American (2007)

eras.label: First Arrivals
eras.headline: Gold Mountain
eras.description: Chinese immigrants — predominantly from Guangdong province — began arriving in San Francisco in 1848 and accelerated dramatically with the Gold Rush. They called San Francisco Gam Saan: Gold Mountain. By 1850, there were 4,000 Chinese in California. By 1852, 25,000. They mined gold, built the transcontinental railroad, farmed the Central Valley, and fished the bay. And they concentrated, for mutual protection and cultural sustenance, in the blocks around Sacramento and Dupont (now Grant) streets.

key_events.event: First Chinese immigrants arrive in San Francisco
25,000 Chinese in California — the largest Chinese community outside China
Transcontinental railroad completed with Chinese labor — many return to SF

eras.landscape: The neighborhood that would become Chinatown was already ethnically distinct by 1852 — Chinese signage, Chinese businesses, Chinese temples in a city that was otherwise a chaos of ethnicities. The buildings were the same wood and brick as the rest of the city. The difference was what happened inside them.
sources: Him Mark Lai, Becoming Chinese American (2004)

eras.label: After the Fire
eras.headline: Rebuilt by Design
eras.description: The 1906 earthquake and fire destroyed Chinatown completely. White civic leaders saw this as an opportunity to relocate the Chinese community to a less desirable area — a proposal that the Chinese community, led by Look Tin Eli, defeated through a brilliant strategic move: they rebuilt Chinatown in a deliberately 'Oriental' architectural style that they knew would attract tourists. The pagoda rooflines and dragon lamp posts that define Chinatown's appearance today were not traditional Chinese architecture — they were a defensive urban strategy.

key_events.event: Earthquake and fire destroys Chinatown entirely
City leaders propose relocating Chinatown to Hunter's Point — the community refuses
Chinatown rebuilt in 'Oriental' style designed to attract tourism and establish permanence

eras.landscape: The rebuilt Chinatown was unlike anything that had existed before — a deliberately constructed orientalist fantasy that was simultaneously a real neighborhood. Dragon lamp posts on Grant Avenue. Pagoda rooflines on buildings with standard American floor plans behind the facades. A Potemkin village that was also a genuine community.
sources: Philip Choy, San Francisco Chinatown: A Guide (1995)

eras.label: Wartime Chinatown
eras.headline: Allies at Last
eras.description: WWII transformed the status of Chinese Americans in San Francisco with brutal irony: China was an American ally against Japan, and suddenly the racism that had defined Chinese life in America for a century was politically inconvenient. The Chinese Exclusion Act was repealed in 1943. Chinese Americans served in the military. The neighborhood that had been a target of discriminatory legislation for sixty years found itself, briefly, welcomed.

key_events.event: Japanese Americans interned — Chinese Americans wear 'I am Chinese' buttons to distinguish themselves
Chinese Exclusion Act repealed after 61 years
Chinese American veterans return to a neighborhood beginning to change

eras.landscape: Grant Avenue during the war was a busy commercial street serving both the Chinese community and the military personnel on leave in San Francisco. The 'Oriental' architecture of the 1907 rebuild now three decades old, beginning to seem authentic through sheer persistence.
sources: Chinese Historical Society of America archives

eras.label: The Six Companies Era
eras.headline: A Neighborhood Under Pressure
eras.description: By 1967 Chinatown was one of the most densely populated neighborhoods in the United States — more than 50,000 people per square mile. The Chinese Six Companies and family associations that had governed the community since the 19th century were facing challenges from younger, American-born Chinese who had different ideas about community governance and political engagement. The Civil Rights movement had created new frameworks for minority communities to demand equity.

key_events.event: Immigration Act ends national origin quotas — Chinese immigration accelerates dramatically
Asian American Political Alliance founded at UC Berkeley — a new generation asserts a political identity
Chinatown demonstrates against urban renewal plans that would have demolished the neighborhood

eras.landscape: The most crowded square footage in San Francisco — apartments stacked above shops, extended families in single rooms, the streets dense with pedestrians at all hours. The architecture of 1907 now weathered and genuine-seeming. Neon signs in Chinese characters above English storefronts.
sources: L. Ling-chi Wang, Politics of Assimilation and Repression (1978)

eras.label: Holding Ground
eras.headline: The Neighborhood That Holds
eras.description: As the dot-com boom drove real estate prices across San Francisco to record levels, Chinatown was one of the few neighborhoods that maintained its character. The combination of community land ownership, political organization built over 150 years of fighting displacement, and the commercial ecosystem that depended on the Chinese community kept the neighborhood stable in a way the Mission could not achieve.

key_events.event: Rose Pak emerges as Chinatown's most powerful political broker, a role she'll hold for two decades
Chinatown maintains its character during the dot-com boom while adjacent neighborhoods transform

eras.landscape: Grant Avenue with its 1907 architecture now genuinely historic. The tourist-facing Grant Avenue and the residential streets behind it — Waverly Place, the alleys, the herb shops and live poultry markets — existing in parallel, the same neighborhood serving two completely different purposes simultaneously.
sources: CCDC (Chinatown Community Development Center) planning records

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Resilient Neighborhood
eras.description: Chinatown in 2025 is the oldest Chinatown in North America and one of the most studied examples of community resilience in urban planning literature. It has survived the Gold Rush, the 1906 earthquake, the Chinese Exclusion Act, WWII internment of Japanese neighbors, urban renewal, three tech booms, and a pandemic that hit its elderly population devastatingly hard. The question of what it means to 'survive' — whether a neighborhood that becomes increasingly a tourist attraction and decreasingly a working community has actually survived — is one the community debates internally.
eras.landscape: Grant Avenue unchanged in its bones from 1910. The alleys and back streets still serving the community that has always lived there, increasingly elderly. Portsmouth Square as the neighborhood's living room, its benches occupied by men playing chess and cards as they have been for a hundred years.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The Question of Continuity
eras.description: The future of Chinatown is a question of what a community means when its founding generation is gone and the diaspora has dispersed across the Bay Area.

future_scenarios.label: Cultural Center
future_scenarios.description: Chinatown has become a cultural institution — the Chinese Historical Society, expanded museums, a living history district. The residents who remain are older; the community's center of gravity has shifted to the Sunset and Richmond districts. Grant Avenue is maintained as heritage.

future_scenarios.label: Living Community
future_scenarios.description: Community land trusts established in the 2020s have kept housing affordable. A new generation of Chinese Americans has moved back. The neighborhood is denser and younger than at any point since 1960. It is genuinely alive, not preserved.

locations.name: Twin Peaks
locations.tagline: The city's highest public viewpoint. Every era of San Francisco written in the skyline below.

eras.label: Sacred Hills
eras.headline: Chutchui and Sutchui
eras.description: The Ramaytush Ohlone called the Twin Peaks Chutchui and Sutchui — a place of spiritual significance, used for ceremony and as a landmark for navigation across the peninsula and bay. From the summit on a clear day, every Ohlone village on the peninsula was visible. The hills were covered in native perennial grasses, coastal scrub, and wind-sculpted trees. The view to the north showed a bay full of salmon and shorebirds, the northern hills bare and brown in summer, green in the brief rainy season.

key_events.event: Ohlone use Twin Peaks as a ceremonial and navigational landmark
Portola expedition members climb to high ground — likely Twin Peaks — to survey the bay

eras.landscape: Native bunchgrass, coyote brush, and coastal scrub to the summit. The view to the north unobstructed by any structure. The bay visible from edge to edge. Grizzly bear and tule elk on the slopes below.
sources: Randall Milliken, A Time of Little Choice (1995)

eras.label: The Lookout
eras.headline: The Spanish Summit
eras.description: The Spanish called the Twin Peaks Los Pechos de la Chola — a name that reflected their particular way of naming the landscape. From the summit, the new settlement of the Presidio was visible to the north. The mission to the south. Between them, the empty peninsula that would become a city.

key_events.event: Spanish name the peaks Los Pechos de la Chola
Presidio and Mission both visible from the summit

eras.landscape: The summit unchanged by the Spanish arrival. Native grasses, coastal scrub. But now: the Presidio visible to the north, the Mission to the south. The first signs of European presence in a 10,000-year-old landscape.
sources: Barbara Berglund, Making San Francisco American (2007)

eras.label: The View Point
eras.headline: Watching the Rush
eras.description: From Twin Peaks in 1849, you could watch the transformation of San Francisco in real time. The cove to the northeast filling with ships. The tent city spreading across the hills. The fires that broke out regularly in the wood and canvas settlement. The hills were still largely open in 1849 — the subdivision of the peninsula was just beginning, and the areas south of Market were still farms and ranchos.

key_events.event: SF population begins its explosive growth — visible from the hills as a spreading settlement
Land speculation reaches the hills south of Market — Twin Peaks parceled and sold

eras.landscape: The summit still bare of any structure. The settlement visible below as a collection of white canvas against dark hills. The bay dotted with ships. The rest of the peninsula empty — open grassland, oak woodland, and the mission visible to the south.

eras.label: After the Fire
eras.headline: The View of the Catastrophe
eras.description: From Twin Peaks on April 18-21, 1906, you could see the entire catastrophe. The smoke column from the burning city was visible from 50 miles away. The glow at night was described by observers as far away as Sacramento. From the summit, the geography of the disaster was clear — where the fire had stopped, where it was still burning, which neighborhoods had been spared.

key_events.event: The fire visible from Twin Peaks across the entire northern and eastern city
Reconstruction visible from the summit — the city rebuilding almost faster than it burned

eras.landscape: From the summit: the northern and eastern city a field of ash and standing facades. The Mission, to the southeast, intact. The western neighborhoods, behind the firebreak of Van Ness Avenue, untouched. The bay, to the north and east, unchanged — cold and indifferent.

eras.label: The Radio Hills
eras.headline: The Signal Hills
eras.description: By 1945 Twin Peaks was crowned with radio transmission towers, its summit chosen for the same reason the Ohlone had valued it: unobstructed sightlines in every direction. The residential neighborhoods had climbed the slopes below the summit. Sutro Tower would not be built for another thirty years, but the infrastructure logic that would produce it was already in place.

key_events.event: Radio transmission towers established on Twin Peaks summit
Twin Peaks Boulevard completed — the first road to the summit, designed for automobiles
From the summit, the city visible in its wartime configuration — blacked out at night, busy at all hours

eras.landscape: The residential grid climbing the lower slopes. The summit cleared for the tower equipment. Sutro's eucalyptus forest to the northwest. The city spreading to every horizon — the great westward expansion of the Richmond and Sunset districts filling in the sand dunes.
sources: SF Recreation and Parks Department history

eras.label: Sutro's Shadow
eras.headline: Sutro Tower Rising
eras.description: Sutro Tower was proposed in 1968 and completed in 1973. The 977-foot television transmission tower — painted red and white to satisfy FAA requirements, its three-pronged top disappearing into fog — became immediately controversial and immediately iconic. From Twin Peaks, Sutro Tower is the dominant vertical element of the western view, simultaneously an eyesore and a beloved landmark.

key_events.event: Sutro Tower proposed — immediately opposed by neighborhood groups
Sutro Tower completed at 977 feet
Harvey Milk and George Moscone assassinated in City Hall — the grief visible across the city

eras.landscape: The residential neighborhoods now complete on every slope below the summit. The natural vegetation at the summit reduced to a small preserve. The city at night a grid of orange sodium lights, Sutro Tower blinking red at its apex, the Bay Bridge's lights reflected in the water.

eras.label: The Dot-com View
eras.headline: The City of Cranes
eras.description: From Twin Peaks during the dot-com boom, the city below was visibly under construction. Cranes in SoMa. The dot-com towers being built along the Embarcadero. The city's skyline adding new elements for the first time since the Financial District high-rise boom of the 1970s. At night, the lights extended further and burned brighter — the city was working around the clock.

key_events.event: Dot-com construction boom visible from Twin Peaks as a forest of cranes in SoMa
San Francisco's population and density at historic highs

eras.landscape: The skyline to the north dense with towers. The construction cranes along the waterfront. At night, the office buildings lit at all hours — the particular brightness of a boom.
sources: SF Planning Department building permit records 1996-2001

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Unchanged View
eras.description: Twin Peaks in 2025 offers the same fundamental experience it offered in 1500 and 1849 and 1906 — a 360-degree view of the peninsula and bay that makes the city's geography suddenly comprehensible. The summit is now a public park, one of the city's most visited. On clear days the view extends to Mount Tamalpais in the north, Mount Diablo to the east, and the Santa Cruz mountains to the south.
eras.landscape: Salesforce Tower dominating the eastern skyline. The Bay Bridge and Golden Gate visible simultaneously. The fog rolling in from the ocean to the west, sometimes submerging the western neighborhoods while the eastern city remains clear. Sutro Tower always visible, always blinking.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The High Ground
eras.description: Twin Peaks will be one of the few parts of San Francisco entirely unaffected by sea level rise — at 925 feet, it will remain above any plausible climate scenario. What will change is what it looks down on.

future_scenarios.label: Resilient City
future_scenarios.description: The view from the summit shows a city that has adapted — seawalls protecting the waterfront, elevated parks along former shorelines, the bay's edge redesigned. The city is denser, smaller in footprint, but still recognizably San Francisco.

future_scenarios.label: Contracted City
future_scenarios.description: The view shows a smaller city. The areas closest to sea level — the Embarcadero, parts of Mission Bay, the lower Mission — have been surrendered to the water or converted to wetlands. The city has contracted to its high ground. From Twin Peaks, the change is stark: the bay is larger than it was.

locations.name: Haight-Ashbury
locations.tagline: The corner where the counterculture was born and the Summer of Love still echoes.

eras.label: Dune Lands
eras.headline: Sand and Scrub
eras.description: Before European contact, the area now known as Haight-Ashbury was part of a vast sand dune system stretching from the ocean to the hills. The Ramaytush Ohlone traversed these dunes seasonally, following game trails between the coast and inland valleys. The sand was soft and wind-sculpted, covered in low coastal scrub and native grasses.

key_events.event: Ohlone inhabit the San Francisco peninsula
Sand dune ecosystem covers the western half of the peninsula
Portolá expedition passes through the area

eras.landscape: Rolling sand dunes covered in lupine, coyote brush, and coastal scrub. The wind from the Pacific constant. No trees — just low vegetation clinging to shifting sand.
sources: Randall Milliken, A Time of Little Choice (1995)

eras.label: Mission Trail
eras.headline: Between the Presidio and the Mission
eras.description: When the Spanish established the Presidio and Mission Dolores in 1776, the area between them was a sandy trail. The future Haight-Ashbury sat along this route, an unremarkable stretch of dunes that soldiers and missionaries crossed on horseback. Rancho San Miguel would eventually encompass this land.

key_events.event: Spanish establish Presidio and Mission Dolores
American conquest of California

eras.landscape: A sandy trail winding through dunes. The Mission visible to the south, the Presidio to the north. Wind-bent scrub and the occasional oak in a sheltered hollow.
sources: Barbara Berglund, Making San Francisco American (2007)

eras.label: Gold Rush Edge
eras.headline: Beyond the City Limits
eras.description: During the Gold Rush, Haight-Ashbury was still far outside the city proper. The settlement hugged the waterfront to the east. Out here, the dunes were being gradually tamed — the first roads surveyed, the first lots platted — but actual development was years away. The area was toll roads and dairy farms.

key_events.event: Gold Rush brings 300,000 people to California
Haight Street surveyed and named for Henry Haight

eras.landscape: Sand dunes giving way to scattered frame houses. The city a distant cluster of buildings to the east. Dairy cattle on the hillsides.

eras.label: Refuge
eras.headline: The Neighborhood That Survived
eras.description: The 1906 earthquake damaged Haight-Ashbury's Victorian houses but the fire never reached this far west. The neighborhood became a refuge for displaced San Franciscans fleeing the burning eastern city. Golden Gate Park, adjacent to the Haight, housed thousands of refugees in tent camps. The neighborhood's survival meant its Victorian architecture was preserved.

key_events.event: Earthquake damages but fire spares the Haight
Golden Gate Park becomes a refugee camp for 40,000 displaced residents
Haight Street becomes a busy commercial corridor

eras.landscape: Rows of painted Victorian houses, their ornament intact. The park to the west full of tents and temporary shelters. The smell of smoke from the burning city carried on the east wind.

eras.label: Working Class
eras.headline: A Streetcar Neighborhood
eras.description: By 1945, Haight-Ashbury was a solidly working-class neighborhood connected to downtown by streetcar lines. The Victorians, now forty to sixty years old, were unfashionable — many subdivided into apartments. The demographic was mixed: white working-class families, some Black residents who had come during the wartime migration.

key_events.event: Wartime workers settle in the neighborhood
Haight-Ashbury a diverse working-class neighborhood

eras.landscape: Streetcars running on Haight Street. The Victorians painted in muted colors. Corner groceries and bars. The park a constant green presence at the western edge.
sources: Charles Perry, The Haight-Ashbury: A History (2005)

eras.label: Summer of Love
eras.headline: The Center of the World
eras.description: In 1967, Haight-Ashbury became the most famous neighborhood on Earth. The Summer of Love drew 100,000 young people to the few blocks around Haight and Ashbury streets. The Grateful Dead lived at 710 Ashbury. Janis Joplin was on Lyon Street. The Diggers gave away free food in the Panhandle. For one impossible summer, the neighborhood was the capital of a revolution that believed love could change everything.

key_events.event: Human Be-In in Golden Gate Park draws 30,000
100,000 young people converge on Haight-Ashbury
Death of Hippie ceremony marks the end of the Summer of Love
Hard drugs replace psychedelics — the neighborhood darkens

eras.landscape: Every Victorian painted in psychedelic colors. Head shops and poster stores on Haight Street. Barefoot crowds filling the sidewalks. Music from every open window. The smell of incense and marijuana. The Panhandle full of people sleeping on the grass.

eras.label: The Branded Counterculture
eras.headline: Nostalgia for Sale
eras.description: By 2000, Haight-Ashbury had become a destination for tourists seeking the ghost of the Summer of Love. The neighborhood was a curious mix: vintage clothing stores next to chain retail, head shops next to upscale restaurants. The Victorians, now recognized as architectural treasures, were being restored at great expense. The counterculture had become a brand.

key_events.event: Victorian restoration drives property values up
Haight Street a tourist destination trading on 1967 nostalgia

eras.landscape: Tie-dye in every shop window. Tourists photographing the Haight-Ashbury street sign. The Victorians immaculately restored in period-appropriate colors. Ben & Jerry's on the corner where the Psychedelic Shop once stood.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Persistent Myth
eras.description: Haight-Ashbury in 2025 still trades on its 1967 mythology, though the neighborhood is now firmly upper-middle-class. The Victorians are worth millions. The street-level retail is a mix of vintage shops, dispensaries, and restaurants. The energy of the Summer of Love exists now only in photographs and in the stories told by tour guides.
eras.landscape: Pristine Victorians in their original colors. Haight Street busy with a mix of tourists, tech workers, and long-time residents. The Panhandle green and peaceful. Golden Gate Park beyond.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: What Survives
eras.description: Haight-Ashbury's Victorian architecture will still be standing in 2075 — these buildings have survived earthquakes, fires, neglect, and gentrification. The question is what the neighborhood means.

future_scenarios.label: Living Museum
future_scenarios.description: The entire neighborhood is a designated historic district. The Victorians are maintained to exacting standards. The Summer of Love is commemorated with plaques and a small museum. The neighborhood is beautiful, expensive, and frozen in time.

future_scenarios.label: New Commons
future_scenarios.description: A community land trust has acquired several blocks. The Victorians house cooperative living arrangements that echo, in a more organized way, the communal experiments of 1967. The neighborhood has found a way to live its mythology rather than just sell it.

locations.name: North Beach
locations.tagline: Where the Beats wrote poetry and the Italians made espresso — San Francisco's literary soul.

eras.label: The Beach
eras.headline: An Actual Beach
eras.description: North Beach was literally a beach — a crescent of sand along the northern shore of the peninsula where the bay met the land. The Ohlone gathered shellfish here and launched tule reed boats. The water came up to what is now Francisco Street.

key_events.event: Ohlone use the north shore for fishing and shellfish gathering
Spanish explorers note the protected cove

eras.landscape: A sandy beach curving along the bay shore. Tule marshes at the edges. Seabirds in vast numbers. The bay clear and cold, full of fish.
sources: Randall Milliken, A Time of Little Choice (1995)

eras.label: Spanish Shore
eras.headline: The Northern Anchorage
eras.description: The Spanish knew this cove as a sheltered anchorage, though they built nothing here. The Presidio sat on the headlands to the west. For the first decades of European presence, North Beach remained what it had always been: a quiet curve of sand.

key_events.event: Presidio established on the headlands west of the beach
Yerba Buena settlement established south of here

eras.landscape: Sand, scrub, and the quiet bay. The Presidio visible on the bluffs to the west. Small boats anchored in the cove.
sources: Barbara Berglund, Making San Francisco American (2007)

eras.label: Little Italy Begins
eras.headline: The First Italians
eras.description: Italian fishermen were among the earliest settlers in North Beach, drawn by the bay's abundant fish and the beach's suitability for launching boats. By the 1850s, the neighborhood had a distinct Italian character — fishermen from Genoa and Sicily establishing the fishing fleet that would feed San Francisco for a century.

key_events.event: Italian fishermen establish camps along the beach
First Italian restaurants open in North Beach
The beach begins to be filled in for development

eras.landscape: Fishing boats pulled up on the sand. Frame buildings climbing the slopes of Telegraph Hill. The smell of fish and wood smoke. Italian spoken in the streets.
sources: Deanna Paoli Gumina, The Italians of San Francisco (1978)

eras.label: Saved by Wine
eras.headline: The Italian Firebreak
eras.description: When the 1906 fire raced toward North Beach, the Italian residents fought it with everything they had — including wine from their cellars, soaking blankets and burlaps when the water mains failed. Parts of North Beach survived that would otherwise have burned. The neighborhood rebuilt quickly, the Italian community too rooted to relocate.

key_events.event: Residents use wine-soaked blankets to fight the approaching fire
North Beach rebuilds — Italian community stays put
Saints Peter and Paul Church construction begins on Washington Square

eras.landscape: Charred blocks adjacent to untouched ones. The randomness of fire. Italian families cooking in the streets. The bay visible from everywhere — the buildings that had blocked the view now gone.
sources: Deanna Paoli Gumina, The Italians of San Francisco (1978)

eras.label: The Neighborhood
eras.headline: Joe DiMaggio's Block
eras.description: By 1945, North Beach was the heart of Italian-American San Francisco. Joe DiMaggio had grown up on Taylor Street, his father fishing from the wharf. The trattorias, delis, and bakeries that define the neighborhood today were already established. Saints Peter and Paul Church presided over Washington Square.

key_events.event: Joe DiMaggio's first season with the Yankees — North Beach's most famous son
Italian Americans navigate wartime suspicion despite deep patriotism
North Beach's Italian identity firmly established

eras.landscape: The aroma of espresso and baking bread. Washington Square green and busy. Fisherman's Wharf at the foot of the hill, the fishing fleet heading out at dawn. Italian conversation in every café.
sources: Deanna Paoli Gumina, The Italians of San Francisco (1978)

eras.label: The Beat Generation
eras.headline: Howl
eras.description: In 1953, Lawrence Ferlinghetti opened City Lights Bookstore on Columbus Avenue. In 1955, Allen Ginsberg read 'Howl' at the Six Gallery. By 1957, North Beach was the capital of the Beat Generation — the neighborhood where Kerouac, Ginsberg, Cassady, and their circle were inventing a new American literature in the cafés and bars between Columbus and Grant.

key_events.event: City Lights Bookstore opens on Columbus Avenue
Allen Ginsberg reads Howl at the Six Gallery
Howl obscenity trial — City Lights wins, making literary history
The Beats make North Beach internationally famous

eras.landscape: Smoky coffeehouses. Poetry readings at midnight. City Lights glowing on Columbus Avenue. The old Italian men watching the young poets with bemused tolerance. Jazz from the clubs on Broadway.
sources: Bill Morgan, The Beat Generation in San Francisco (2003)
Lawrence Ferlinghetti, A Coney Island of the Mind (1958)

eras.label: Italian-Beat Fusion
eras.headline: Two Mythologies
eras.description: By 2000, North Beach ran on two overlapping mythologies: the Italian neighborhood and the Beat neighborhood. City Lights was still open, still independent, still radical. The Italian restaurants were still family-owned. The neighborhood had resisted the homogenization that had transformed other San Francisco neighborhoods.

key_events.event: City Lights designated a historic landmark
North Beach maintains its dual Italian-literary identity amid dot-com transformation

eras.landscape: City Lights' neon sign reflected in the wet pavement. The trattorias full on weekend nights. Washington Square unchanged. Telegraph Hill and Coit Tower above everything.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: Still the Village
eras.description: North Beach in 2025 retains more of its character than almost any San Francisco neighborhood. City Lights is still open. The Italian restaurants endure. Washington Square still hosts bocce players on Sunday mornings. The neighborhood feels like a small town inside a city — the rarest thing in modern San Francisco.
eras.landscape: Columbus Avenue on a warm evening — every sidewalk table occupied. The smell of garlic and espresso. City Lights' windows full of poetry. Coit Tower lit against the night sky on Telegraph Hill above.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The Last Bookstore District
eras.description: North Beach's future depends on whether physical gathering places — bookstores, cafés, restaurants — survive the shift to digital everything.

future_scenarios.label: Literary Quarter
future_scenarios.description: North Beach becomes a formally designated literary and cultural district, with protections for independent bookstores, performance spaces, and artist housing. City Lights anchors a neighborhood that has become, deliberately, a haven for physical culture in an increasingly virtual world.

future_scenarios.label: Beat Museum District
future_scenarios.description: The neighborhood trades entirely on nostalgia. Every business references the Beats or the Italians. The culture is gone but the brand remains — an open-air museum of San Francisco's literary past, visited by tourists who have never read Howl.

locations.name: Lower Manhattan
locations.tagline: Where New Amsterdam became New York and money became the language of the world.

eras.label: Lenape Island
eras.headline: Mannahatta
eras.description: The Lenape people called it Mannahatta — island of many hills. The southern tip was a rocky promontory covered in old-growth forest, with streams running to the harbor. The Lenape fished these waters, gathered oysters from beds so vast they formed small islands, and traded with communities across the harbor.

key_events.event: Lenape settlements along the southern shore of Manhattan
Giovanni da Verrazzano sails into the harbor — first European contact
Henry Hudson sails up the river that will bear his name

eras.landscape: Old-growth forest to the water's edge. Massive oyster beds in the harbor. Streams running through ravines. The harbor teeming with fish, seals, and whales.
sources: Eric Sanderson, Mannahatta: A Natural History (2009)

eras.label: New Amsterdam Falls
eras.headline: From Dutch to English
eras.description: In 1664, an English fleet appeared in the harbor and demanded the surrender of New Amsterdam. Director-General Peter Stuyvesant wanted to fight, but the colonists refused. The Dutch surrendered without a shot. New Amsterdam became New York. The wall that the Dutch had built across the island's southern tip to defend against the English — it ran roughly along today's Wall Street.

key_events.event: Peter Minuit purchases Manhattan from the Lenape
Wall built across lower Manhattan for defense — future Wall Street
English capture New Amsterdam — rename it New York
Wall demolished — the street keeps the name

eras.landscape: A small colonial town at the island's tip. The wall running east-west. Dutch gabled houses, a church, a fort. The harbor full of merchant ships. Beyond the wall, farmland stretching north.
sources: Russell Shorto, The Island at the Center of the World (2004)

eras.label: First Capital
eras.headline: Where Washington Took the Oath
eras.description: On April 30, 1789, George Washington stood on the balcony of Federal Hall at the corner of Wall and Broad Streets and took the oath of office as the first President of the United States. New York was the nation's first capital. Wall Street was already becoming a financial center — the Buttonwood Agreement that would create the New York Stock Exchange was five years away.

key_events.event: George Washington inaugurated at Federal Hall on Wall Street
Capital moves to Philadelphia — New York continues as financial center
Buttonwood Agreement — traders organize under a tree on Wall Street

eras.landscape: Federal Hall at the head of Wall Street. Brick buildings, church spires, the mast forest of ships in the harbor. The street already lined with banks and counting houses.

eras.label: Draft Riots
eras.headline: A City at War with Itself
eras.description: In July 1863, the Civil War came to Lower Manhattan in the form of the Draft Riots — the deadliest civil disturbance in American history. Working-class New Yorkers, many of them Irish immigrants, attacked draft offices, Black residents, and symbols of wealth. The violence lasted four days. Federal troops fresh from Gettysburg were brought in to restore order. Wall Street erected barricades.

key_events.event: Draft Riots — four days of violence across Lower Manhattan
War ends — New York's banks have financed the Union victory
Black Friday — Jay Gould attempts to corner the gold market

eras.landscape: Barricades on Wall Street. Smoke from fires across the Lower East Side. Federal troops with fixed bayonets. The contrast between the wealth of the financial district and the poverty of the surrounding neighborhoods made visible in violence.
sources: Iver Bernstein, The New York City Draft Riots (1990)

eras.label: The Crash
eras.headline: Black Tuesday
eras.description: On October 29, 1929, the stock market lost $14 billion in a single day. Crowds gathered on Wall Street, staring at the Stock Exchange as though the building itself might explain what had happened. The crash triggered the Great Depression, ending an era of speculation that had transformed Lower Manhattan into a canyon of skyscrapers. The very architecture of the neighborhood — massive, confident, vertical — suddenly seemed like a monument to hubris.

key_events.event: Black Thursday — market loses 11% at opening
Black Tuesday — $14 billion lost in a single day
40 Wall Street completed — briefly the world's tallest building
Glass-Steagall Act regulates the banking industry

eras.landscape: The canyon of Wall Street — stone and steel towers blocking the sky. Crowds on the sidewalk reading ticker tape. The Stock Exchange's columned facade. Above everything, the new skyscrapers reaching upward even as the economy fell.
sources: John Kenneth Galbraith, The Great Crash 1929 (1955)

eras.label: Near Death
eras.headline: The City on the Brink
eras.description: By 1977, New York City had nearly gone bankrupt. Lower Manhattan was emptying — businesses fleeing to the suburbs, the streets dangerous after dark. The famous Daily News headline: 'Ford to City: Drop Dead.' Wall Street survived, but the neighborhood around it was a ghost town at night. The buildings that had symbolized American ambition now stood half-empty.

key_events.event: New York City fiscal crisis — near bankruptcy
Blackout and looting across New York City
Financial district begins slow recovery

eras.landscape: Empty streets after 6 PM. The magnificent buildings dark and underused. Trash in the gutters. The harbor neglected. A neighborhood of enormous wealth that felt, at street level, abandoned.

eras.label: September 11
eras.headline: The Day the Towers Fell
eras.description: On September 11, 2001, two planes struck the World Trade Center towers at the southern tip of Manhattan. Both towers collapsed. 2,977 people died. The physical destruction was concentrated in a few blocks, but the psychic destruction extended to every corner of the city and the world. Lower Manhattan was evacuated, covered in ash, and closed for weeks.

key_events.event: World Trade Center towers destroyed in terrorist attack
Ground Zero recovery and cleanup
Freedom Tower design selected — later renamed One World Trade Center

eras.landscape: The absence. Where the towers had been, a void. Ash covering everything for blocks in every direction. Missing persons flyers on every surface. The smell that lingered for months. The sky visible where it had not been visible before.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: Rebuilt and Transformed
eras.description: Lower Manhattan in 2025 is transformed. One World Trade Center stands where the Twin Towers fell. The 9/11 Memorial pools mark the footprints of the original towers. The Financial District has become residential — thousands of apartments in converted office buildings. The neighborhood that was empty at night is now full of families and restaurants.
eras.landscape: One World Trade Center catching the light. The memorial pools reflecting the sky. Stone Street's restaurants full on a weeknight. The harbor alive with ferries. A neighborhood that has found new life after the worst day in its history.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The Edge of the Water
eras.description: Lower Manhattan sits barely above sea level. By 2075, the relationship between the island and the water that surrounds it will be the defining challenge.

future_scenarios.label: The Big U
future_scenarios.description: A massive seawall and park system protects Lower Manhattan from storm surge and sea level rise. The infrastructure transforms the waterfront into elevated public space. The neighborhood survives, denser and more resilient than before.

future_scenarios.label: Managed Retreat
future_scenarios.description: Some of the lowest blocks near the waterfront have been surrendered to the rising water. The financial district has moved inland and upward. The memorial pools are now protected behind flood barriers. The edge of Manhattan is wet and wild.

locations.name: Brooklyn Bridge
locations.tagline: The bridge that connected two cities and became the symbol of a nation's ambition.

eras.label: The Crossing
eras.headline: The East River
eras.description: Before the bridge, the East River separated Manhattan from Brooklyn — two distinct landmasses connected only by ferry. The Lenape crossed by canoe. The river was a tidal strait, dangerous and cold, separating communities that could see each other across the water but could not easily reach each other.

key_events.event: Lenape cross the East River by canoe
First ferry service across the East River

eras.landscape: A wide tidal strait, the water dark and fast-moving. Manhattan visible from the Brooklyn shore — close enough to shout across, too far to swim.

eras.label: Dutch Crossing
eras.headline: Two Colonies
eras.description: Under Dutch rule, Brooklyn (Breuckelen) and Manhattan were separate communities connected by ferry. The crossing was unreliable — dependent on weather, tides, and the ferryman's schedule. The dream of a permanent crossing was already forming.

key_events.event: Regular ferry service established
English take both Manhattan and Brooklyn

eras.landscape: Flat-bottomed ferry boats crossing the choppy strait. Brooklyn's farms visible from Manhattan's waterfront. The crossing took thirty minutes on a good day.
sources: Russell Shorto, The Island at the Center of the World (2004)

eras.label: The Growing Need
eras.headline: Ferries and Frustration
eras.description: By the late 18th century, the ferry crossing between Manhattan and Brooklyn was one of the busiest in the world. Walt Whitman would write about it decades later — the crowds, the waiting, the beauty of the water. But the inconvenience was enormous. Ice in winter could stop all traffic for days.

key_events.event: Brooklyn ferry carries thousands of commuters daily
Steam ferry introduced — faster but still weather-dependent

eras.landscape: Crowded ferry terminals on both shores. The river busy with boats of every size. Frustration visible in the faces of commuters waiting for the next crossing.

eras.label: Roebling's Vision
eras.headline: The Impossible Bridge
eras.description: In 1867, John Augustus Roebling proposed a suspension bridge across the East River — the longest in the world. He died from an accident during early construction. His son Washington Roebling took over, then was crippled by caisson disease. His wife Emily effectively directed the project. The bridge took 14 years and 27 lives to build.

key_events.event: John Roebling proposes the bridge
Roebling dies — son Washington takes over
Washington Roebling crippled by caisson disease — Emily directs construction
Brooklyn Bridge opens — 150,000 people cross on the first day

eras.landscape: The towers rising from the river, Gothic arches in granite. The cables spinning out in geometric perfection. Workers high above the water. The two cities watching from their respective shores.

eras.label: The Icon
eras.headline: The Most Beautiful Bridge
eras.description: By 1929, the Brooklyn Bridge had been joined by the Manhattan and Williamsburg bridges, but it remained the most beautiful — the Gothic towers and cable web recognized worldwide. Hart Crane published The Bridge in 1930, cementing the structure's place in American literature. It had become more than infrastructure — it was a national symbol.

key_events.event: Manhattan Bridge opens
Hart Crane publishes The Bridge
Brooklyn Bridge a symbol of American engineering worldwide

eras.landscape: The bridge at sunrise, its cables catching the light. The wooden pedestrian walkway above the traffic lanes. The view of Manhattan's growing skyline from the Brooklyn side.

eras.label: Decay and Beauty
eras.headline: The Crumbling Icon
eras.description: By the 1970s, the Brooklyn Bridge was literally falling apart. Decades of deferred maintenance had left the structure deteriorating. Cables were frayed. Concrete was crumbling. A major rehabilitation began in 1982 that would take a decade. Even in decay, the bridge remained breathtaking.

key_events.event: Bridge deterioration becomes critical
Major rehabilitation begins — will take until 1992

eras.landscape: Rust and beauty together. The cables still magnificent against the sky, but the roadway crumbling. Construction scaffolding around the towers. The bridge beautiful even in its worst condition.
sources: NY Department of Transportation bridge reports

eras.label: September Light
eras.headline: The Walk Home
eras.description: On September 11, 2001, when the subways stopped and the tunnels closed, hundreds of thousands of people walked across the Brooklyn Bridge to escape Lower Manhattan. The dust from the fallen towers covered the walkway. The bridge, built to connect two cities, became an escape route — the longest walk home anyone had ever taken.

key_events.event: Hundreds of thousands walk across the bridge fleeing Manhattan
Bridge's 120th anniversary — celebrated as a symbol of resilience

eras.landscape: The walkway covered in white dust. Thousands of people walking east, away from the smoke. The towers gone from the skyline for the first time in thirty years. The bridge holding, as it always had.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Eternal Walk
eras.description: The Brooklyn Bridge walkway is one of the most walked paths in the world. Millions cross it annually — tourists, commuters, joggers, lovers. The view of the Manhattan skyline, framed by the Gothic arches and cable web, remains one of the most photographed perspectives on Earth.
eras.landscape: The wooden walkway crowded with people from everywhere on Earth. The cables forming geometric patterns against the sky. One World Trade Center visible through the arches. The harbor sparkling below.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: Still Standing
eras.description: The Brooklyn Bridge will be 192 years old in 2075. The granite towers are essentially eternal. The cables and roadway will need continuous maintenance. The bridge will outlast almost everything around it.

key_events.event: Bridge's 167th birthday — oldest operating suspension bridge in the world

eras.landscape: The Gothic towers against whatever skyline exists in 2075. The cables still spinning their web. The walkway still carrying people across the water. Some things endure.

future_scenarios.label: Eternal Monument
future_scenarios.description: The bridge is still in daily use, maintained to the highest standards as both infrastructure and monument. It remains the most beautiful bridge in the world. The pedestrian walkway is busier than ever.

future_scenarios.label: Pedestrian Bridge
future_scenarios.description: Vehicle traffic has been permanently removed. The entire bridge is a pedestrian and cycling path — a linear park above the water. The experience of crossing is quieter and more contemplative than it has been in a century.

locations.name: South Bank
locations.tagline: Shakespeare's side of the river — where London kept its theaters, its pleasures, and its secrets.

eras.label: Londinium
eras.headline: The Roman South
eras.description: When the Romans built Londinium in 43 AD, the south bank of the Thames was marshy and sparsely settled. The Romans built their bridge — the first London Bridge — connecting the main settlement on the north bank to the road south to the Channel ports. The south bank was a suburb from the start.

key_events.event: Romans found Londinium
First London Bridge built
Boudicca's revolt destroys Londinium — rebuilt within a decade

eras.landscape: Marshland along the south bank of a wide, tidal river. The Roman town visible across the water — red tile roofs, a forum, the bridge. Reed beds and wading birds on the Southwark shore.

eras.label: Norman London
eras.headline: The Borough
eras.description: After the Norman Conquest, Southwark — 'the southern work' — became established as London's southern gateway. The road from the Channel crossed the bridge here. Inns clustered near the bridgehead. The Borough developed its own character: less regulated, more chaotic, always slightly disreputable.

key_events.event: Norman Conquest — William crosses London Bridge
Stone London Bridge begun — will take 33 years to complete

eras.landscape: A cluster of inns and taverns near the bridgehead. The Thames broad and slow, full of boats. The tower of Southwark Cathedral rising above the rooftops. The road south beginning at the bridge.

eras.label: Shakespeare's Bankside
eras.headline: All the World's a Stage
eras.description: In the late 1500s, London's authorities banned theaters from the City proper. So the players crossed the river. The Globe Theatre opened on Bankside in 1599. Shakespeare's company performed here — Hamlet, Othello, King Lear, all first seen on the south bank of the Thames. The area was also home to bear-baiting pits, brothels, and taverns. The south bank was where London went to be entertained.

key_events.event: Rose Theatre built on Bankside
Globe Theatre opens — Shakespeare's company performs
Globe burns during a performance of Henry VIII
