Globe rebuilt — will operate until 1642

eras.landscape: The thatched roof of the Globe visible from the river. The roar of 3,000 spectators. Bear-baiting pits nearby. The north bank's church spires visible across the water, respectable and disapproving.
sources: James Shapiro, A Year in the Life of William Shakespeare (2005)

eras.label: Industrial South
eras.headline: The Dark Side of the River
eras.description: By 1851, the south bank had become London's industrial zone — warehouses, wharves, breweries, and the desperate poverty of Dickens's novels. The Great Exhibition was in Hyde Park on the north bank; the south bank was where the workers who built it lived. The area was notorious for crime, poverty, and pollution.

key_events.event: First railway into London — London Bridge Station on the south bank
Great Exhibition — south bank workers build the Crystal Palace they cannot afford to enter
Great Stink — the Thames so polluted Parliament cannot sit

eras.landscape: Warehouses crowding the riverbank. The water brown and foul. Railway viaducts cutting through the neighborhood. The contrast with the north bank visible from every bridge.

eras.label: The Blitz
eras.headline: Fire on the River
eras.description: During the Blitz of 1940-41, the south bank was devastated. The warehouses burned spectacularly — full of oil, timber, and goods. The fires were so intense they could be seen from the Channel. The destruction cleared vast areas, creating the blank canvas on which the modern South Bank would be built.

key_events.event: Blitz begins — south bank warehouses burn for days
Continued bombing devastates Southwark
War ends — vast areas of the south bank are rubble

eras.landscape: Warehouses burning along the river. The water reflecting the flames. Fireboats on the Thames. The dome of St. Paul's visible through the smoke across the river — miraculously unburned.

eras.label: Festival of Britain
eras.headline: A New Beginning
eras.description: In 1951, the Festival of Britain was held on the bombed-out south bank — a deliberate statement of renewal. The Royal Festival Hall was built for the occasion and is still in use today. The festival reimagined the south bank as a cultural destination rather than an industrial zone. The Southbank Centre that exists today traces directly to this moment.

key_events.event: Festival of Britain opens on the south bank
Royal Festival Hall completed — still standing
National Theatre and other brutalist cultural buildings added

eras.landscape: The Royal Festival Hall gleaming white on the riverbank. Festival crowds enjoying the new public spaces. The bombsites being transformed. A south bank reimagined as a place of culture rather than industry.
sources: Becky Conekin, The Autobiography of a Nation (2003)

eras.label: The Millennium Mile
eras.headline: London's Living Room
eras.description: By 2000, the south bank transformation was complete. The Tate Modern opened in the converted Bankside Power Station. The Millennium Bridge connected it to St. Paul's Cathedral. The South Bank was now 'London's living room' — a continuous walkway of theaters, galleries, restaurants, and public spaces stretching from Westminster Bridge to Tower Bridge.

key_events.event: Shakespeare's Globe reconstruction opens
Tate Modern opens in the converted Bankside Power Station
Millennium Bridge opens — connects Tate Modern to St. Paul's

eras.landscape: The Tate Modern's massive turbine hall. Skateboarders under the brutalist undercroft. Book stalls along the riverside walk. The Thames clean enough for fish, the skyline a mix of old and new.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Cultural Shore
eras.description: The South Bank in 2025 is one of the great public spaces in the world. From the London Eye to Tower Bridge, the riverside walk is continuous — a four-mile promenade of theaters, galleries, restaurants, and street performers. The area that Shakespeare knew as the entertainment district has come full circle.
eras.landscape: The Thames Walk on a warm evening. The National Theatre lit up. Tate Modern's chimney against the sky. St. Paul's dome framed by the Millennium Bridge. Street performers, food stalls, the river flowing past.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The River Rises
eras.description: The Thames is tidal and London is slowly sinking. The south bank's future is inseparable from the river's behavior.
eras.landscape: The Thames Walk in 2075 — whatever it looks like, the river will still be there, and people will still walk beside it.

future_scenarios.label: Barrier City
future_scenarios.description: A new Thames Barrier, downstream of the current one, protects the south bank from increasingly severe storm surges. The cultural institutions have been flood-proofed. The river walk is elevated in places, creating a layered public space.

future_scenarios.label: Amphibious Quarter
future_scenarios.description: The south bank has embraced the water rather than fighting it. Floating performance spaces and galleries extend into the river. The boundary between land and water is intentionally blurred. Shakespeare would recognize the spirit, if not the architecture.

locations.name: City of London
locations.tagline: The original square mile. Two thousand years of power in the world's oldest continuous financial center.

eras.label: Londinium
eras.headline: Roman Capital
eras.description: The Romans chose this spot for practical reasons: the Thames was narrow enough to bridge but deep enough for ocean-going ships. By 100 AD, Londinium was the largest city in Britannia — a grid of streets, a forum, an amphitheater, bathhouses, and a bridge. The Roman wall that enclosed the city defined its boundaries for the next 1,500 years.

key_events.event: Romans establish Londinium
Boudicca destroys the city — rebuilt larger
Roman wall built — defines the City's boundaries until the modern era

eras.landscape: Roman streets in a grid. Red tile roofs. The forum where Leadenhall Market now stands. The bridge crowded with carts. Ships from across the Empire in the river.

eras.label: Norman Conquest
eras.headline: The Tower Goes Up
eras.description: William the Conqueror built the Tower of London at the City's eastern edge in 1066 — a statement of military dominance over the wealthiest city in his new kingdom. The City negotiated: it accepted Norman rule in exchange for keeping its ancient liberties. This deal — power in exchange for autonomy — defined the City's relationship with every subsequent ruler.

key_events.event: William builds the Tower of London
City granted charter preserving its liberties
White Tower completed — visible from every point in the City

eras.landscape: The White Tower rising above the old Roman wall. Norman soldiers patrolling. The City's merchants continuing their business under new management. The river busy with trade.

eras.label: The Great Fire
eras.headline: London Burns
eras.description: On September 2, 1666, a fire started in a bakery on Pudding Lane and burned for four days, destroying 13,200 houses, 87 churches, and old St. Paul's Cathedral. The medieval City was erased. Christopher Wren rebuilt it — 51 churches, a new St. Paul's, and a city of stone and brick where wood had been. The City that exists today is essentially Wren's City.

key_events.event: Fire starts in Pudding Lane bakery
Fire extinguished — 80% of the City destroyed
Wren rebuilds St. Paul's Cathedral
Wren designs 51 new churches across the City

eras.landscape: Ash and ruins. The medieval city gone. Then, rising from the ash: Wren's new skyline — the dome of St. Paul's, the spires of 51 churches, a city rebuilt in stone.
sources: Adrian Tinniswood, By Permission of Heaven (2003)

eras.label: Victorian Finance
eras.headline: The Empire's Bank
eras.description: By 1851, the City of London was the financial capital of the world. The Bank of England, the Stock Exchange, Lloyd's of London — every institution that financed the British Empire was within the Square Mile. The population was declining — the City was becoming a place where people worked, not lived — but its power was at its zenith.

key_events.event: Bank of England given sole right to issue banknotes
City of London finances the Great Exhibition
Overend, Gurney & Co. collapse — last major City bank failure for 140 years

eras.landscape: Top hats and frock coats on Threadneedle Street. The Bank of England massive and windowless. Horse-drawn carriages. The dome of St. Paul's above everything.
sources: David Kynaston, The City of London (2011)

eras.label: The Blitz
eras.headline: St. Paul's Survives
eras.description: The Blitz devastated the City of London. On the night of December 29, 1940, incendiary bombs created a firestorm that destroyed the area around St. Paul's Cathedral. But the cathedral survived — thanks to the volunteer fire watch on its roof. The photograph of St. Paul's dome rising above the smoke became the iconic image of London's defiance.

key_events.event: Firestorm destroys the area around St. Paul's — the cathedral survives
Continued bombing destroys most of the City's remaining medieval buildings
War ends — the City is largely rubble

eras.landscape: St. Paul's dome floating above a sea of fire and smoke. The most famous photograph of the Blitz. Below, the City burning. The dome untouched, its lead-covered timber framework intact.

eras.label: The New City
eras.headline: Towers Rise
eras.description: In the 1960s, the City rebuilt itself with modernist towers — sweeping away the remnants of Wren's streetscape for concrete and glass. The Barbican Centre and its housing estate, begun in 1965, represented the most ambitious attempt to bring residents back to the Square Mile. The skyline began its transformation from Wren's spires to modern towers.

key_events.event: Barbican estate construction begins
Centre Point tower completed
City's resident population at an all-time low of 4,000

eras.landscape: Construction cranes among Wren's surviving spires. Brutalist concrete next to Portland stone. The City remaking itself again, as it had after every fire and war.

eras.label: The Gherkin Era
eras.headline: London's New Skyline
eras.description: The construction of 30 St Mary Axe (the Gherkin) in 2003 began a wave of distinctive towers that transformed the City's skyline. The Walkie Talkie, the Cheesegrater, the Scalpel — each with a nickname, each controversial. For the first time since Wren, the City's skyline was being actively designed.

key_events.event: 30 St Mary Axe (The Gherkin) completed
Wave of distinctive towers transforms the City skyline

eras.landscape: The Gherkin's curved glass against the sky. St. Paul's dome now surrounded by towers. The old and new in constant visual conversation. The City's skyline more dramatic than at any point in its 2,000-year history.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Square Mile
eras.description: The City of London in 2025 remains the world's most concentrated financial district. Half a million people commute into the Square Mile every day; fewer than 10,000 live there. The skyline is a palimpsest — Roman wall fragments next to Wren churches next to glass towers. The Lord Mayor still processes through streets laid out by the Romans.
eras.landscape: The skyline at dusk — St. Paul's dome, the Gherkin, the Shard across the river, cranes building the next tower. Streets that follow Roman routes. Money moving at the speed of light through buildings that took centuries to build.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The Enduring Mile
eras.description: The City of London has reinvented itself after every catastrophe for 2,000 years. The Square Mile in 2075 will face climate adaptation, AI disruption of finance, and the continued question of whether physical proximity matters for the movement of money.
eras.landscape: Whatever the City looks like in 2075, St. Paul's dome will still be there. The Roman wall fragments will still be there. The money will still be there, in whatever form it takes.

future_scenarios.label: Algorithmic City
future_scenarios.description: The trading floors are empty — AI handles everything. But the City has adapted before. The buildings now house the humans who oversee the algorithms: regulators, ethicists, and the occasional trader who remembers when it was done by hand. The restaurants are still full at lunch.

future_scenarios.label: Green Square Mile
future_scenarios.description: The City has reinvented itself as the global center for climate finance. The towers are net-zero. The streets are planted with trees. The money still flows, but now it flows toward survival.

locations.name: Diriyah
locations.tagline: The birthplace of the Saudi state — where mud-brick walls hold the memory of a kingdom's founding.

eras.label: The Founding
eras.headline: Wadi Hanifa
eras.description: Diriyah was founded in 1446 by Mani' Al-Muraydi, ancestor of the Al Saud dynasty, on the banks of Wadi Hanifa. The valley provided water in one of the driest places on Earth. The settlement grew around date palm groves and mud-brick houses, a small oasis town in the vast Najd desert.

key_events.event: Mani' Al-Muraydi founds Diriyah
Diriyah grows as a trading settlement on the Wadi Hanifa

eras.landscape: Mud-brick houses along the wadi. Date palm groves. The desert stretching in every direction. The sound of water — rare and precious — in the valley.
sources: Madawi Al-Rasheed, A History of Saudi Arabia (2010)

eras.label: The First Saudi State
eras.headline: The Pact
eras.description: In 1744, Muhammad ibn Saud, ruler of Diriyah, formed an alliance with the religious reformer Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab. This pact — political power joined with religious authority — created the First Saudi State. Diriyah became the capital of a realm that at its height stretched from the Persian Gulf to the Red Sea.

key_events.event: Pact between Ibn Saud and Ibn Abd al-Wahhab
First Saudi State — Diriyah as capital
Diriyah becomes the largest city in central Arabia

eras.landscape: At-Turaif palace complex rising above the wadi. Mud-brick towers and walls. Caravans arriving from across the peninsula. A capital city built of earth, governing a desert empire.
sources: Madawi Al-Rasheed, A History of Saudi Arabia (2010)

eras.label: Destruction
eras.headline: The Ottoman Siege
eras.description: In 1818, an Ottoman-Egyptian army besieged and destroyed Diriyah. Ibrahim Pasha's forces demolished the At-Turaif palace complex and the city's walls. The last ruler of the First Saudi State was sent to Istanbul and executed. Diriyah was left in ruins — a deliberate attempt to erase the Saudi state from history.

key_events.event: Ottoman-Egyptian forces destroy Diriyah
At-Turaif palace complex demolished
Saudi capital moves to Riyadh — Diriyah remains in ruins

eras.landscape: Shattered mud-brick walls. The palace complex reduced to foundations. Palm groves burned. The wadi flowing past ruins that had been, six months earlier, the capital of an empire.
sources: Madawi Al-Rasheed, A History of Saudi Arabia (2010)

eras.label: Rebirth Elsewhere
eras.headline: The Distant Capital
eras.description: In 1902, Abdulaziz ibn Abdul Rahman Al Saud captured Riyadh and began rebuilding the Saudi state. Diriyah remained a ruin — symbolic but abandoned. The new capital was Riyadh, 20 kilometers south. Diriyah's ruins stood as a reminder of what had been lost and what was being rebuilt.

key_events.event: Abdulaziz captures Riyadh — begins Third Saudi State
Unification of Saudi Arabia — Diriyah remains symbolic ruins

eras.landscape: Crumbling mud-brick walls above the wadi. Date palms growing wild through the ruins. Riyadh visible to the south, growing. Diriyah frozen in time.

eras.label: Oil Changes Everything
eras.headline: The Old World Fades
eras.description: The discovery of oil in 1938 transformed Saudi Arabia from a desert kingdom into a global power. Riyadh began its explosive growth. Diriyah, the founding site, became a small village overshadowed by the modern capital expanding toward it.

key_events.event: Oil discovered in Saudi Arabia
Riyadh begins modern expansion
Diriyah absorbed into greater Riyadh's sprawl

eras.landscape: The mud-brick ruins now surrounded by modern development. Concrete replacing earth. The wadi still flowing, but the city growing around it. The old world and the new, side by side.

eras.label: Preservation Begins
eras.headline: Remembering the Founding
eras.description: As Saudi Arabia modernized at dizzying speed, the government began recognizing Diriyah's historical importance. Preservation efforts started in the 1970s. The At-Turaif district was stabilized and studied. The ruins that the Ottomans had tried to erase were now being carefully preserved.

key_events.event: Saudi government begins Diriyah preservation
At-Turaif designated a national heritage site
Archaeological surveys of the ruins begin

eras.landscape: Archaeologists working among the mud-brick walls. The ruins being stabilized. Modern Riyadh visible in every direction. The contrast between the ancient earthen walls and the glass towers on the horizon.
sources: Saudi Commission for Tourism and National Heritage

eras.label: UNESCO World Heritage
eras.headline: Global Recognition
eras.description: In 2010, the At-Turaif District of Diriyah was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The Saudi government announced a massive development plan — the Diriyah Gate project — to transform the area into a cultural and entertainment destination while preserving the historic core.

key_events.event: At-Turaif inscribed as UNESCO World Heritage Site
Diriyah Gate development project announced
Major restoration and development work begins

eras.landscape: The mud-brick walls restored to their original profile. Construction cranes surrounding the historic site. The past being preserved while the future is built around it.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Founding Place
eras.description: Diriyah in 2025 is being transformed. The At-Turaif ruins are meticulously restored. The Diriyah Gate project is creating a cultural quarter with museums, hotels, and public spaces. Saudi Arabia's founding site is becoming a destination — a place where the kingdom's history is being actively told.
eras.landscape: Restored mud-brick walls glowing in the desert light. New cultural buildings in sympathetic materials. The wadi as a linear park. The founding place of a kingdom, reinvented for a new era.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The Living Origin
eras.description: Diriyah's future is tied to Saudi Arabia's post-oil transformation. As the kingdom reinvents itself, its founding site takes on new meaning.
eras.landscape: The mud-brick walls will still be standing — they've survived since 1446. What surrounds them will tell the story of where Saudi Arabia went next.

future_scenarios.label: Cultural Capital
future_scenarios.description: Diriyah has become one of the Middle East's premier cultural destinations. The At-Turaif ruins anchor a district of museums, galleries, and performance spaces. The founding site of the Saudi state is now its cultural heart.

future_scenarios.label: Smart Heritage City
future_scenarios.description: Diriyah integrates advanced technology into heritage preservation — AR overlays show the city as it was in 1744, climate systems protect the mud-brick walls, and the site serves as a model for heritage preservation in extreme climates worldwide.

locations.name: The Empty Quarter
locations.tagline: The largest sand desert on Earth. Emptiness as a form of infinity.

eras.label: Before Memory
eras.headline: The Sea of Sand
eras.description: The Rub' al Khali — the Empty Quarter — is the largest contiguous sand desert on Earth. 650,000 square kilometers of dunes, some reaching 250 meters high. The Bedouin knew it as a place of extremes: temperatures exceeding 50°C, no permanent water, and a silence so complete it could drive a person mad.

key_events.event: Climate change transforms the region from savanna to desert
Bedouin tribes navigate the desert's edges

eras.landscape: Sand dunes stretching to every horizon. The color shifting from gold to red to white. No vegetation, no water, no sound except the wind moving sand. Stars visible in numbers that defy counting.

eras.label: Bedouin Paths
eras.headline: The Crossing Routes
eras.description: By the 18th century, Bedouin tribes had mapped invisible routes across the Empty Quarter — paths known only by memory, following chains of water sources separated by days of travel. The desert was not truly empty. It was inhabited by people who understood it so deeply they could survive where others could not.

key_events.event: Bedouin trade routes cross the desert's edges
The Empty Quarter is the last unmapped region on the Arabian Peninsula

eras.landscape: A Bedouin caravan moving across the dunes at dawn. Camels in single file. The navigator reading the sand and stars. Survival measured in sips of water.

eras.label: The Unknown
eras.headline: Terra Incognita
eras.description: In the early 19th century, the Empty Quarter remained one of the last blank spaces on European maps. No Western explorer had crossed it. The desert existed as a rumor — tales of lost cities, of the legendary Ubar, of sand dunes that swallowed caravans. The reality was more extreme than any legend.

key_events.event: British surveys map the desert's northern edge — the interior remains unknown
The Empty Quarter remains uncharted by European explorers

eras.landscape: The edge of the known world. Maps showing blank space. The dunes beginning at the horizon and extending into infinity.

eras.label: First Crossing
eras.headline: Bertram Thomas Walks Through
eras.description: In 1931, British explorer Bertram Thomas became the first Westerner to cross the Empty Quarter. The journey took 58 days, with Bedouin guides. He nearly died of thirst twice. The crossing was a sensation — one of the last great exploration achievements on Earth. Wilfred Thesiger would follow in 1946-47.

key_events.event: Bertram Thomas crosses the Empty Quarter — first European to do so
St. John Philby crosses by a different route
Wilfred Thesiger makes two crossings — writes Arabian Sands

eras.landscape: A small party of men and camels against an ocean of sand. The dunes rising hundreds of meters. The sun like a physical weight. Water measured in hours of survival.

eras.label: Oil Beneath the Sand
eras.headline: The Hidden Fortune
eras.description: The discovery of oil in Saudi Arabia in 1938 transformed the Empty Quarter from a wasteland into the most valuable real estate on Earth. Beneath the sand lay the Ghawar field and the Shaybah field — among the largest oil reserves ever found. The emptiest place on the planet contained the fuel that would power the modern world.

key_events.event: Oil discovered in Saudi Arabia
Exploration begins in the Empty Quarter
Shaybah field discovered beneath the dunes

eras.landscape: Geologists with seismic equipment on the dunes. The realization that beneath millions of years of sand lay millions of years of oil. The desert unchanged on the surface. Everything changed beneath it.

eras.label: Shaybah
eras.headline: City in the Desert
eras.description: In 1998, Saudi Aramco opened the Shaybah oil production facility in the heart of the Empty Quarter. Building it required constructing a 640-kilometer road across the dunes. The facility produces 750,000 barrels per day from a place where no human lived permanently before. Shaybah is one of the most remote industrial installations on Earth.

key_events.event: Shaybah oil facility opens in the Empty Quarter
Production expands to 750,000 barrels per day
Aramco begins carbon capture experiments at Shaybah

eras.landscape: An oil processing facility gleaming in the desert sun. Pipelines running to the horizon. Air-conditioned buildings housing workers who fly in for shifts. The dunes unchanged a kilometer away.

eras.label: Solar Potential
eras.headline: The New Energy
eras.description: The Empty Quarter receives more solar radiation per square meter than almost anywhere on Earth. By 2010, Saudi Arabia was beginning to think about the desert not just as an oil reserve but as a solar energy resource. The irony was not lost on anyone: the desert that had powered the fossil fuel age could power the renewable age.

key_events.event: Saudi Arabia announces solar energy ambitions
Vision 2030 includes massive renewable energy targets
First solar projects near the Empty Quarter announced

eras.landscape: Solar panels beginning to appear at the desert's edge. The same sun that made the desert uninhabitable now being harvested. Oil wells and solar farms sharing the landscape.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: Between Two Energies
eras.description: The Empty Quarter in 2025 sits between two energy eras. Oil still flows from Shaybah. Solar projects are expanding at the desert's margins. The dunes themselves are unchanged — they were here before oil and will be here after it. The question is what humans do with the energy beneath and above the sand.
eras.landscape: The dunes at dawn, gold and red. An oil facility visible to the south. Solar panels glinting to the north. The desert itself indifferent to the human argument about energy. Stars at night in numbers that exist nowhere else.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: After Oil
eras.description: The Empty Quarter will still be empty in 2075. The question is whether it will still be relevant — or whether it returns to the silence it held for millennia.
eras.landscape: The dunes will still be here. The wind will still move the sand. What changes is whether anyone has a reason to be here.

future_scenarios.label: Solar Sea
future_scenarios.description: The Empty Quarter hosts the largest solar installation on Earth — thousands of square kilometers of panels generating power for the entire Gulf region. The desert that powered the oil age now powers the solar age. Workers commute by autonomous vehicle across roads that cross the dunes.

future_scenarios.label: Return to Silence
future_scenarios.description: The oil facilities are decommissioned. The solar installations are elsewhere, in less extreme locations. The Empty Quarter returns to what it was: the largest sand desert on Earth, empty again, visited only by those who seek the particular peace of infinite sand.

locations.name: Downtown
locations.tagline: The downtown that nobody wanted — until everyone did.

eras.label: Tongva Land
eras.headline: Yang-na
eras.description: The Tongva people called this place Yang-na. The Los Angeles River, before it was channeled into concrete, was a real river — seasonal but powerful, sustaining a network of villages across the basin. Yang-na was one of the largest, situated near a natural spring where the river bent.

key_events.event: Tongva village of Yang-na thrives near the LA River
Juan Cabrillo sails past — first European contact with the California coast

eras.landscape: A river flowing through a broad valley. Oak woodland and grassland. The mountains visible in every direction — the San Gabriels to the north, the Santa Monicas to the west. Tongva houses of willow and tule.

eras.label: El Pueblo
eras.headline: The Founding
eras.description: On September 4, 1781, 44 settlers — a mix of Spanish, Indigenous, Black, and mestizo people — founded El Pueblo de Los Ángeles. It was a farming community, dependent on the river. The original plaza still exists today, near Olvera Street. The diversity of the founders would define LA forever.

key_events.event: El Pueblo de Los Ángeles founded by 44 settlers
Population reaches 600
US captures Los Angeles in the Mexican-American War

eras.landscape: A small adobe settlement around a central plaza. The river nearby. Cattle grazing on the hillsides. The mountains visible and close. A farming village in an enormous landscape.

eras.label: American Conquest
eras.headline: The Flag Changes
eras.description: In 1848, the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo ended the Mexican-American War. Los Angeles became American territory. The population was 1,600 — still a farming pueblo. The great transformation was decades away, but the legal framework that would enable it — American property law, American capital — was now in place.

key_events.event: US forces capture Los Angeles
Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo — California becomes US territory
California becomes a state — LA incorporated as a city

eras.landscape: Adobe buildings around the old plaza. Ranchos stretching in every direction. The river still flowing naturally. An American flag where the Mexican flag had flown.

eras.label: The Boom
eras.headline: The City of Angels Rises
eras.description: Between 1900 and 1910, LA's population grew from 100,000 to 320,000 — the fastest growth of any American city. Downtown was the center of everything: the Pacific Electric Railway hub, the first movie studios, oil derricks visible from Broadway. Bunker Hill was the city's most fashionable residential neighborhood, its Victorian mansions overlooking the growing city.

key_events.event: Oil discovered in downtown LA
Pacific Electric Railway connects downtown to the basin
Hollywood merges with LA — the movie industry begins

eras.landscape: Victorian mansions on Bunker Hill. The Pacific Electric cars running down every boulevard. Oil derricks on the hillsides. The extraordinary energy of a city being invented from scratch.

eras.label: Noir City
eras.headline: The City of Night
eras.description: Post-war downtown LA was the city of Raymond Chandler and film noir — a dark, glamorous place of nightclubs, private detectives, and corruption. Broadway was the entertainment district, with twelve movie palaces within a six-block stretch. Bunker Hill's mansions were now rooming houses. The freeways were coming.

key_events.event: Film noir defines LA's image — dark, glamorous, corrupt
Streetcar system begins to be dismantled
Freeway construction transforms downtown

eras.landscape: Neon signs on Broadway. Movie palaces with ornate facades. The last streetcars running. The freeway overpasses beginning to shadow the streets. Film noir shot on these actual corners.

eras.label: Demolition
eras.headline: Bunker Hill Erased
eras.description: In the 1960s, LA demolished Bunker Hill — the entire Victorian neighborhood razed for urban renewal. The grand houses, the funicular railway (Angels Flight), the rooming houses, the bohemian community — all bulldozed. In their place: the blank concrete plazas and towers of the Music Center and corporate offices. One of the great acts of urban destruction in American history.

key_events.event: Bunker Hill urban renewal begins — Victorian neighborhood demolished
Music Center opens on the cleared hilltop
Angels Flight funicular dismantled — the hill is gone

eras.landscape: Bulldozers on the hilltop. Victorian mansions being demolished. The bare earth of Bunker Hill, stripped of everything that had made it a neighborhood. Corporate towers rising in their place.
sources: Don Parson, Making a Better World (2005)

eras.label: The Return
eras.headline: Lofts and Galleries
eras.description: After decades as a 9-to-5 ghost town, downtown LA began to revive around 2000. The Adaptive Reuse Ordinance allowed office buildings to be converted to lofts. Artists moved into the warehouse district. The galleries followed. Then the restaurants. For the first time in fifty years, people were choosing to live downtown.

key_events.event: Adaptive Reuse Ordinance passes — office-to-loft conversions begin
Walt Disney Concert Hall opens — Frank Gehry's masterpiece
Downtown residential population grows from 18,000 to 50,000

eras.landscape: Gehry's Concert Hall gleaming on Bunker Hill. Loft buildings with rooftop bars. The old Broadway theaters being restored. A downtown finding its pulse after decades of silence.
sources: Christopher Hawthorne, LA architecture criticism, LA Times

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Contested Center
eras.description: Downtown LA in 2025 is contested territory. Luxury towers next to tent encampments. The Arts District thriving while Skid Row endures. The city's wealth and poverty, its ambition and its failures, all concentrated in a few square miles. Downtown is both LA's showcase and its mirror.
eras.landscape: The skyline from the 6th Street Bridge. Disney Concert Hall catching the sunset. The tent cities visible from the freeway. The contradictions of Los Angeles at their most concentrated.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: Center or Sprawl
eras.description: The question for downtown LA in 2075: does the city develop a true center, or does the sprawl continue to dissolve any notion of centrality?
eras.landscape: The skyline will be different. The freeways may be different. The question is whether downtown becomes the heart of the city or remains one node among many.

future_scenarios.label: Transit City
future_scenarios.description: The Metro system, finally mature, has made downtown the transit hub it was always meant to be. Density has increased dramatically. Downtown is walkable, bikeable, and for the first time in LA's history, feels like a real city center. The freeways are being converted to boulevards.

future_scenarios.label: Many Downtowns
future_scenarios.description: LA has embraced its polycentric nature. Downtown is one center among many — Hollywood, Santa Monica, Long Beach, Pasadena all equally vital. The attempt to create a single center has been abandoned in favor of a network of connected nodes.

locations.name: Venice Beach
locations.tagline: Abbot Kinney's impossible dream — an Italian Venice on the Pacific, where California invents itself daily.

eras.label: Tongva Shore
eras.headline: The Pacific Edge
eras.description: The Tongva people fished and gathered along this stretch of coast for millennia. The wetlands behind the beach — now the Venice canals — were rich ecosystems supporting abundant wildlife. The shore was a meeting place between land and ocean, between the Tongva villages inland and the resources of the sea.

key_events.event: Tongva villages dot the coast
Cabrillo expedition sails past

eras.landscape: A wide, flat beach backed by salt marshes and wetlands. Pelicans, herons, seals. The Tongva launching boats through the surf. The Santa Monica Mountains visible to the north.

eras.label: Rancho Land
eras.headline: The Cattle Coast
eras.description: After the Spanish founding of LA, this coastal land became part of the Rancho La Ballona. Cattle grazed the salt marshes. The coast was essentially uninhabited — too marshy for farming, too remote from the pueblo. For a century, it was left to the cattle and the birds.

key_events.event: Rancho La Ballona granted — cattle graze the wetlands
American conquest

eras.landscape: Salt marsh and dunes. Cattle wandering the shore. The Pacific stretching to the horizon. Nothing suggesting that this would become one of the most famous beaches in the world.
sources: Leonard Pitt, The Decline of the Californios (1966)

eras.label: American Shore
eras.headline: The Coast Changes Hands
eras.description: After the Mexican-American War, the California coast became American territory. Rancho La Ballona, which included the future Venice, was confirmed to its Mexican owners under American law. But the tide of American settlement was rising. Within decades, the ranchos would be subdivided.

key_events.event: California becomes US territory
Rancho La Ballona subdivided

eras.landscape: The coast unchanged by the change of government. Cattle on the salt marshes. The Pacific breaking on the empty shore. Land speculators beginning to arrive.
sources: Leonard Pitt, The Decline of the Californios (1966)

eras.label: Venice of America
eras.headline: Kinney's Dream
eras.description: In 1905, tobacco millionaire Abbot Kinney built Venice of America — a resort town with Italian-style canals, gondolas, a pier, and an arcade colonnade modeled on St. Mark's Square. It was absurd, ambitious, and briefly magnificent. Gondoliers actually poled visitors through canals fed by the ocean. The development drew thousands.

key_events.event: Abbot Kinney opens Venice of America
Gondolas imported from Italy, gondoliers hired
Most canals filled in to make roads — only a few survive

eras.landscape: Colonnaded arcades along canals reflecting the California sun. Gondolas with singing gondoliers. A fantasy of Italy built on a California marsh. Crowds arriving by Pacific Electric Railway.
sources: Jeffrey Stanton, Venice California: Coney Island of the Pacific (1987)

eras.label: Oil and Beatniks
eras.headline: The Bohemian Shore
eras.description: By the 1940s, Venice was rough around the edges. The canals that hadn't been filled in were stagnant. Oil derricks pumped along the shore. But the cheap rents attracted artists, writers, and beatniks. The Venice West Café became a Beat hangout. Lawrence Lipton wrote The Holy Barbarians about the Venice Beat scene.

key_events.event: Venice annexed by LA — loses independence
Oil derricks along the Venice shore
Venice West Café — Beat poetry readings on the boardwalk

eras.landscape: Oil derricks silhouetted against the sunset. The boardwalk weathered and peeling. Beatniks in the cafés. The canal houses sagging. Cheap, beautiful, and slightly dangerous.

eras.label: The Counterculture Shore
eras.headline: Pacific Counterculture
eras.description: Venice in the late 1960s was the Pacific coast counterpart to San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury — a place where the counterculture met the ocean. Jim Morrison lived on the canals. The Doors played their first gigs in Venice bars. The beach became a gathering place for surfers, hippies, and artists.

key_events.event: Jim Morrison moves to Venice — writes early Doors songs on the rooftop
Venice becomes a center of the Southern California counterculture
Dogtown surfing culture begins to develop

eras.landscape: Psychedelic murals on the beach buildings. Surfboards leaning against every wall. Music from open windows. The smell of salt and incense. The most casual counterculture in America.
sources: Barney Hoskyns, Waiting for the Sun (1996)

eras.label: Gentrification Arrives
eras.headline: Silicon Beach
eras.description: The 2000s brought tech money to Venice. Google, Snapchat, and dozens of startups moved into the area known as Silicon Beach. Abbot Kinney Boulevard was named 'The Coolest Block in America' by GQ. Rents quadrupled. The artists who had made Venice interesting were being pushed out by the people who wanted to be near interesting artists.

key_events.event: Google opens Venice office
Snapchat founded on Venice's Speedway
Abbot Kinney Blvd named 'coolest block' by GQ

eras.landscape: Tesla-lined Abbot Kinney Boulevard. Tech workers in the coffee shops that were once artist hangouts. The boardwalk still chaotic. The canals now lined with multimillion-dollar homes.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Beautiful Contradiction
eras.description: Venice Beach in 2025 is LA's most concentrated contradiction. The boardwalk — still wild, still strange — sits adjacent to some of the most expensive real estate in California. Muscle Beach, skate parks, street performers, and tent encampments coexist within blocks of $5 million canal houses.
eras.landscape: The boardwalk at golden hour. Skaters, buskers, tourists, tech workers, houseless residents. The Pacific reflecting the sky. Snapchat's headquarters behind the palm trees. The most beautiful mess in California.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The Rising Pacific
eras.description: Venice Beach sits barely above sea level. The Pacific is rising. The canals that Abbot Kinney built as fantasy may become involuntary reality.
eras.landscape: The beach will change. The ocean will take some of what was built. The question is whether Venice adapts or retreats.

future_scenarios.label: Amphibious Venice
future_scenarios.description: Venice has embraced its name's destiny. The canals are expanded, not fought. Houses are elevated. The boardwalk is a seawall. Venice becomes, accidentally, what Kinney always wanted: a city that lives with water rather than against it.

future_scenarios.label: Fortified Shore
future_scenarios.description: A massive seawall protects the Venice coast. The boardwalk is elevated. The character is preserved but the relationship with the ocean has changed — the water is held back by engineering, not welcomed.

locations.name: The Loop
locations.tagline: The city that works — built twice, burned once, and never stopped moving.

eras.label: Potawatomi Land
eras.headline: The Wild Onion
eras.description: The Potawatomi called this place Checagou — the place of the wild onion, or the place of the bad smell, depending on interpretation. The site was strategic: a short portage connected the Great Lakes watershed to the Mississippi River system. Whoever controlled this portage controlled trade between two-thirds of the continent.

key_events.event: Potawatomi and other tribes use the Chicago portage
Marquette and Jolliet pass through — first Europeans

eras.landscape: A flat, marshy plain at the edge of a vast lake. Wild onions and garlic in the wetlands. The river sluggish and brown. The lake stretching to the horizon like an ocean.

eras.label: Incorporation
eras.headline: A City from Nothing
eras.description: Chicago was incorporated as a city in 1837 with a population of 4,000. It sat on a swamp. The streets were mud. The buildings were wood. But the location — at the junction of lake, river, and prairie — made it inevitable. Within twenty years it would be one of the largest cities in America.

key_events.event: Town of Chicago established — population 200
City of Chicago incorporated — population 4,000
Illinois & Michigan Canal opens — Chicago becomes a shipping hub

eras.landscape: A flat grid of muddy streets. Wooden buildings barely above the swamp. The lake to the east, prairie in every other direction. An unlikely city in an impossible location.

eras.label: The Great Fire
eras.headline: The City Burns
eras.description: On October 8, 1871, the Great Chicago Fire destroyed 3.3 square miles of the city center, killed 300 people, and left 100,000 homeless. The wooden city burned for three days. But Chicago rebuilt with extraordinary speed — within two years, the downtown was largely reconstructed, this time in stone, brick, and the new material that would define Chicago: steel.

key_events.event: Great Chicago Fire begins
Fire extinguished — 3.3 square miles destroyed
Rebuilding begins immediately — the city rises from the ashes in under two years

eras.landscape: The entire city center in flames. The sky red for three days. The lake the only escape. Then: ash. Then: rebuilding. The city's defining act: to burn and to rebuild.
sources: Carl Smith, Urban Disorder and the Shape of Belief (1995)

eras.label: The White City
eras.headline: World's Fair
eras.description: The 1893 World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago was a turning point for American architecture and urbanism. The 'White City' — Daniel Burnham's neoclassical fairground — attracted 27 million visitors and established Chicago as a city of architectural ambition. The Loop's commercial buildings, designed by Sullivan, Burnham, and Root, were inventing the skyscraper.

key_events.event: Home Insurance Building — world's first skyscraper
World's Columbian Exposition — 27 million visitors
Loop elevated railway completed — gives the district its name

eras.landscape: The White City on the lakefront. Neoclassical palaces in plaster. The elevated railway circling the downtown — the Loop named for the route. Sullivan's ornament on the new skyscrapers.
sources: Erik Larson, The Devil in the White City (2003)

eras.label: Century of Progress
eras.headline: Depression and Defiance
eras.description: Chicago's 1933 Century of Progress Exposition opened in the depths of the Great Depression — a deliberate act of civic defiance. The Loop itself was struggling. But the city's essential character — brash, ambitious, unbreakable — was on display. The Art Deco buildings going up along Michigan Avenue were statements of faith in a future that seemed impossible.

key_events.event: St. Valentine's Day Massacre — Chicago's gangster era at its peak
Century of Progress Exposition opens on the lakefront
Art Deco buildings transform the Loop's skyline

eras.landscape: Art Deco towers rising on Michigan Avenue. The Loop's elevated trains clattering overhead. The Depression visible in the faces on State Street. The exposition on the lakefront — lights and optimism against economic despair.

eras.label: The Year of Fire
eras.headline: A City Divided
eras.description: In April 1968, after Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination, Chicago burned. The West Side riots destroyed blocks of the city. Mayor Daley's 'shoot to kill' order horrified the nation. Four months later, the Democratic National Convention brought police violence against protesters to national television. Chicago in 1968 was a city at war with itself.

key_events.event: MLK assassination triggers riots — West Side burns
Democratic National Convention — police riot against protesters
Chicago becomes a symbol of American division

eras.landscape: Smoke rising from the West Side. National Guard on State Street. The Loop barricaded. Grant Park full of protesters and tear gas. A city that had survived fire and depression facing something harder: its own contradictions.

eras.label: Millennium Park
eras.headline: The New Civic Space
eras.description: Millennium Park, opened in 2004, transformed the Loop's relationship with the lakefront. Anish Kapoor's Cloud Gate (the Bean), Frank Gehry's Pritzker Pavilion, and Jaume Plensa's Crown Fountain created a new civic center. For the first time in decades, people came to the Loop not just to work but to gather.

key_events.event: Millennium Park opens — Cloud Gate becomes Chicago's most photographed object
Residential conversion brings people back to the Loop

eras.landscape: Cloud Gate reflecting the skyline. The Pritzker Pavilion's steel ribbons. Families on the Great Lawn. The Loop, for the first time, feeling like a neighborhood rather than just a workplace.
sources: Blair Kamin, Chicago Tribune architecture coverage

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Resilient City
eras.description: The Loop in 2025 is adapting. Remote work has emptied some office towers, but the residential population is growing. Millennium Park draws millions. The architecture remains extraordinary — from Sullivan to Mies to Gehry, the Loop is an open-air museum of American building.
eras.landscape: The elevated train clattering around the Loop. Cloud Gate reflecting a hundred faces. The Chicago River green in spring. State Street busy with shoppers. The skyline that defined American architecture, still defining it.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The Next Architecture
eras.description: Chicago has reinvented itself through architecture after every crisis. The question for 2075: what does the next reinvention look like?
eras.landscape: The Loop will still have the elevated train. It will still have the lake. What it builds next is the question.

future_scenarios.label: Adaptive Reuse City
future_scenarios.description: The office towers of the 20th century are converted to mixed-use: housing, vertical farms, community spaces. The Loop becomes a residential neighborhood for the first time. The architecture is preserved but the use is transformed.

future_scenarios.label: Lakefront Fortress
future_scenarios.description: Rising lake levels and more extreme weather have required massive infrastructure investment. The lakefront is redesigned as a climate buffer. The Loop is protected by engineering as ambitious as the buildings it defends.

locations.name: South Side
locations.tagline: Where the Great Migration found its voice and Black America built a city within a city.

eras.label: Prairie
eras.headline: The Flat Land
eras.description: Before the city, this was prairie — flat grassland stretching south from the lake. The Potawatomi hunted here. The land was impossibly fertile, the grasses taller than a person. No one imagined a city here.

key_events.event: Potawatomi use the prairie south of the Chicago River

eras.landscape: Tall grass prairie to the horizon. The lake to the east. No trees, no hills — just grass and sky and the sound of wind.

eras.label: The Grid Laid
eras.headline: Parceled Prairie
eras.description: When Chicago was platted in the 1830s, the grid extended south across the prairie. The lots were sold to speculators. The area was farmland, then suburbia, then city — the familiar American sequence of land becoming real estate.

key_events.event: Chicago's grid extends south
Railroad lines cut through the South Side

eras.landscape: Farm fields being subdivided into city lots. The grid of streets extending across flat land. Railroad tracks laid through what was, a year before, a farm.

eras.label: After the Fire
eras.headline: The Fire Stops Here
eras.description: The Great Chicago Fire of 1871 burned north and east but stopped before reaching the South Side. The area became a refuge for displaced families, then a destination for the massive immigration that followed the fire. The South Side's growth as a distinct part of Chicago began with the fire's aftermath.

key_events.event: Great Fire spares the South Side — refugees arrive
Irish, German, and Eastern European immigrants settle the South Side

eras.landscape: Wooden houses on the flat prairie. Smoke from the burning city visible to the north. Refugees arriving with whatever they could carry. The South Side becoming, by default, a place of new beginning.
sources: Carl Smith, Urban Disorder and the Shape of Belief (1995)

eras.label: The Exposition Edge
eras.headline: White City's Shadow
eras.description: The 1893 World's Fair was built on the South Side, in Jackson Park. The White City brought global attention. But the neighborhoods around the fairground were already becoming racially segregated. After the fair, the South Side's demographic transformation accelerated.

key_events.event: World's Fair built on the South Side
Fair demolished — but its presence has transformed the area
Black population begins to concentrate on the South Side

eras.landscape: The White City gleaming at the lakefront. The neighborhoods behind it already divided by race. The fair's promise of progress and the reality of segregation, side by side.
sources: Erik Larson, The Devil in the White City (2003)

eras.label: The Great Migration
eras.headline: Bronzeville Is Born
eras.description: Between 1910 and 1920, 50,000 Black Americans moved to Chicago's South Side as part of the Great Migration. Confined by racial covenants to a narrow strip of the South Side, they built Bronzeville — a city within a city. The Chicago Defender newspaper, founded in 1905, had encouraged the migration. What they built was extraordinary.

key_events.event: Robert Abbott founds the Chicago Defender
Great Migration brings 50,000 Black Southerners to Chicago
Chicago Race Riot — white mobs attack Black residents, 38 killed
Bronzeville becomes the cultural capital of Black America

eras.landscape: The Stroll along 47th Street — jazz clubs, businesses, churches, newspapers, all Black-owned. The density of forced segregation producing, against all odds, cultural brilliance. Louis Armstrong playing at the Sunset Café.
sources: Isabel Wilkerson, The Warmth of Other Suns (2010)

eras.label: The Projects
eras.headline: A Dream Deferred
eras.description: In the 1950s and 60s, Chicago built massive public housing projects on the South Side — the Robert Taylor Homes, Stateway Gardens, Cabrini-Green. They were designed to contain the Black population. The buildings were deliberately placed to maintain segregation. What had been a vibrant community was increasingly isolated and underserved.

key_events.event: Robert Taylor Homes construction begins — will house 27,000 people
Emmett Till's funeral in Chicago — 100,000 view the open casket
MLK campaigns in Chicago — calls it 'the most segregated city in America'

eras.landscape: The towers of the Robert Taylor Homes stretching for two miles along State Street. The deliberate architecture of containment. The vibrant community persisting despite the buildings designed to isolate it.

eras.label: Demolition and Renewal
eras.headline: The Towers Come Down
eras.description: Starting in the late 1990s, Chicago demolished its high-rise public housing projects. The Robert Taylor Homes, Stateway Gardens, Cabrini-Green — all torn down, replaced by mixed-income developments. The residents were scattered. The demolitions were controversial: some called it renewal, others called it displacement.

key_events.event: Chicago Housing Authority Plan for Transformation begins
Robert Taylor Homes fully demolished
Barack Obama elected president — from Chicago's South Side

eras.landscape: Empty lots where the towers stood. Mixed-income townhouses rising in their place. The former residents scattered across the metropolitan area. The South Side asking what comes next.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Beautiful Struggle
eras.description: The South Side in 2025 is in transition. Investment is arriving but unevenly. The Obama Presidential Center is under construction in Jackson Park. Bronzeville is gentrifying. The South Side's cultural legacy — gospel, blues, jazz, hip-hop, literature — remains one of the most important in American history.
eras.landscape: The Obama Presidential Center rising in Jackson Park. New development on Cottage Grove. Empty lots next to new construction. The cultural richness that survives every political failure. Chicago's South Side, still building.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: What Bronzeville Becomes
eras.description: The South Side's future is inseparable from the question of racial justice in America. What was built here — against enormous odds — will either be preserved or gentrified away.
eras.landscape: The South Side in 2075. The question is not what is built but who it is built for.

future_scenarios.label: Community Renaissance
future_scenarios.description: Community land trusts and cooperative ownership have preserved Bronzeville's character while allowing investment. The cultural legacy is alive, not museumified. The South Side is thriving on its own terms.

future_scenarios.label: New South Loop
future_scenarios.description: The South Side has been fully absorbed into the expanding downtown. The architecture is new, the residents are new, and Bronzeville exists as a name on a real estate listing. The cultural heritage is commemorated in plaques on buildings where different people now live.

locations.name: Lagos Island
locations.tagline: Africa's original megacity — where twenty million people create the future in real time.

eras.label: The Awori Settlement
eras.headline: Eko
eras.description: The Awori people, a Yoruba subgroup, settled Lagos Island around the 14th century. They called it Eko — a camp or a garden. The island sat in a vast lagoon system, protected from the Atlantic surf by barrier islands. It was a fishing community connected by water to the mainland and to the trading networks that stretched across West Africa.

key_events.event: Awori settle Lagos Island — call it Eko
Lagos becomes part of the Benin Empire's sphere of influence

eras.landscape: A low island in a lagoon. Fishing boats drawn up on the shore. Palm-thatched houses. The lagoon stretching to the mainland. Mangroves at the water's edge.

eras.label: Portuguese Arrival
eras.headline: The Slave Coast
eras.description: In 1472, Portuguese explorer Rui de Sequeira arrived at the lagoon and named it Lagos, after a port city in Portugal. Within decades, Lagos became a major point on the transatlantic slave trade. The island's protected lagoon made it ideal for loading human cargo onto ships. For four centuries, the slave trade would define Lagos.

key_events.event: Portuguese arrive — name the city Lagos
Lagos becomes a major slave trading port
Slave trade intensifies — Lagos one of the busiest ports on the coast

eras.landscape: Portuguese ships in the lagoon. The slave market on the island. A place of extraordinary cruelty becoming, against all odds, a great city.
sources: Robin Law, Ouidah: The Social History of a West African Slaving Port (2004)

eras.label: Slave Port
eras.headline: The Trade in Humans
eras.description: By 1700, Lagos was one of the busiest slave trading ports in West Africa. The lagoon system provided protected waters for loading enslaved people onto European ships. The Oba of Lagos controlled the trade, extracting tribute from European merchants. Hundreds of thousands of people passed through Lagos in chains.

key_events.event: Lagos one of the major slave ports on the Bight of Benin
Lagos exports an estimated 5,000-10,000 enslaved people per year
Britain abolishes the slave trade — enforcement is slow

eras.landscape: European ships in the lagoon. The slave market on the island. Barracoons — holding pens — along the shore. The human cargo of the Atlantic trade passing through this small island.
sources: Toyin Falola, The History of Nigeria (2008)

eras.label: British Colony
eras.headline: The Colonial City
eras.description: In 1861, the British bombarded Lagos and established colonial rule — ostensibly to suppress the slave trade they had profited from for centuries. Lagos became a Crown Colony and the administrative center of British Nigeria. The island was developed with colonial infrastructure: government houses, churches, a railway terminal. The indigenous population was displaced to the margins.

key_events.event: British bombard Lagos — impose a compliant ruler
Lagos formally annexed as a Crown Colony
Lagos linked by railway to the interior

eras.landscape: Colonial government buildings on the waterfront. The railway terminal connecting the island to the mainland. Churches and mosques. The overlay of British administration on an African city.
sources: Ade Ajayi, Milestones in Nigerian History (2003)

eras.label: Amalgamation
eras.headline: Capital of Nigeria
eras.description: In 1914, the British amalgamated their northern and southern Nigerian territories, with Lagos as the capital. The island was now the administrative center of the most populous country in Africa. The colonial city was designed for a fraction of the population it served. The overcrowding that would define Lagos began here.

key_events.event: Nigeria amalgamated — Lagos becomes the capital
Lagos population reaches 100,000
Nationalist movements begin — Lagos is the center of agitation

eras.landscape: A colonial capital bursting at the seams. Government buildings, markets, mosques, churches — all crowded onto an island never designed for this intensity. The energy of a city outgrowing its boundaries.
sources: Ade Ajayi, Milestones in Nigerian History (2003)

eras.label: Independence
eras.headline: Freedom Day
eras.description: On October 1, 1960, Nigeria became independent. Lagos was the capital of the new nation — the most populous country in Africa, rich in oil, full of ambition. The celebrations on Lagos Island were enormous. The promise was vast. The city's population was 750,000 and growing explosively.

key_events.event: Nigerian independence — Lagos the capital
Oil boom begins — Lagos grows at breakneck speed
Nigerian Civil War — Lagos remains the capital

eras.landscape: Independence celebrations on the island. Flags and music and the enormous hope of a new nation. The city already too crowded, already too exciting, already unstoppable.
sources: Wole Soyinka, You Must Set Forth at Dawn (2006)

eras.label: Megacity
eras.headline: Twenty Million
eras.description: By 2000, Lagos had become one of the largest cities on Earth — an estimated 13 million people, growing toward 20 million. The capital had moved to Abuja in 1991, but Lagos remained the economic and cultural capital. Lagos Island was now just the historic core of a megacity that stretched for miles in every direction. The energy was staggering.

key_events.event: Capital moves to Abuja — Lagos remains the economic heart
Lagos population estimated at 13 million
Eko Atlantic land reclamation begins offshore

eras.landscape: The Third Mainland Bridge packed with traffic at all hours. Markets overflowing from every available space. The skyline of Lagos Island — a mix of colonial and modern. A city of pure energy, overwhelming and unstoppable.
sources: Rem Koolhaas, Lagos: How It Works (2006)

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The African Metropolis
eras.description: Lagos in 2025 is a city of over 20 million people. Lagos Island remains the symbolic center — the financial district, the markets, the oldest neighborhoods. Eko Atlantic, the new city being built on reclaimed land offshore, represents the future. Nollywood, Afrobeats, tech startups — Lagos is generating culture at a pace that rivals any city on Earth.
eras.landscape: The chaos and brilliance of Lagos Island. Markets stacked to the sky. Traffic that defies description. Music everywhere. The most kinetic city on the planet, making it up as it goes.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: Africa's Century
eras.description: Lagos in 2075 will be one of the largest cities in human history — projected population of 50 to 80 million. How it grows will shape the future of urbanization worldwide.
eras.landscape: A city of 50 million or more. The scale is almost beyond imagining. Lagos will be what it has always been: a place that makes the impossible ordinary.

future_scenarios.label: Smart Megacity
future_scenarios.description: Lagos has leapfrogged traditional infrastructure. Mobile payments, distributed solar, water recycling, and AI-managed traffic have created a megacity that works despite — or because of — its scale. The innovation is African-led and globally exported.

future_scenarios.label: Amphibious City
future_scenarios.description: Sea level rise has transformed Lagos's lagoon geography. The city has responded with floating neighborhoods, elevated markets, and water-based transit. Makoko, once called a slum, is now the model for the entire city. Lagos floats.

locations.name: Victoria Island
locations.tagline: Where Nigeria's wealth meets the Atlantic — the gleaming face of Africa's largest economy.

eras.label: Barrier Island
eras.headline: Sand and Surf
eras.description: Victoria Island was a barrier island separating the Lagos Lagoon from the Atlantic Ocean. Uninhabited, battered by surf, it was a strip of sand and mangrove. The Awori people fished the waters around it but saw no reason to settle on an island exposed to the open ocean.

key_events.event: Barrier island — uninhabited, used for fishing

eras.landscape: A narrow strip of sand between lagoon and ocean. Coconut palms bent by the Atlantic wind. Surf crashing on the ocean side, calm lagoon water on the other.

eras.label: Colonial Outpost
eras.headline: Named for the Queen
eras.description: The British named the island after Queen Victoria when they colonized Lagos. It remained largely undeveloped through the colonial period — too exposed to the ocean, too far from the administrative center on Lagos Island. A few colonial officials built beach houses.

key_events.event: Named Victoria Island under British colonial rule
Colonial beach houses built

eras.landscape: A quiet, sandy island with a few colonial structures. The ocean on one side, the lagoon on the other. Palms and tropical vegetation. A place for weekends, not for work.

eras.label: The Empty Shore
eras.headline: Between Ocean and Lagoon
eras.description: While Lagos Island bustled with the slave trade, Victoria Island remained a sandy barrier island — uninhabited, battered by Atlantic waves, separating the lagoon from the open ocean. Fishermen crossed it to reach the sea. It had no settlement, no name, no significance beyond its geography.

key_events.event: Victoria Island remains uninhabited — used only for fishing access

eras.landscape: Sand, surf, mangroves. Coconut palms. The roar of the Atlantic on the ocean side, the calm of the lagoon on the other. Birds nesting. No human structures.

eras.label: Slow Development
eras.headline: The Quiet Island
eras.description: Through the early 20th century, Victoria Island remained a backwater — connected to Lagos Island by ferry, sparsely developed, known mainly for its beaches. The real city was on Lagos Island and the mainland. Victoria Island waited.

key_events.event: Victoria Island remains mostly undeveloped
Some residential development begins

eras.landscape: Sandy roads, scattered houses, the beach. Ferry boats connecting to Lagos Island. The pace of the island wholly unlike the intensity of the city across the water.

eras.label: Independence Era
eras.headline: The New Neighborhood
eras.description: After independence in 1960, Victoria Island began to develop as an elite residential neighborhood. Diplomats, executives, and politicians built houses there. The bar beach was the city's premier recreational spot. The island was connected to Lagos Island by a bridge, accelerating development.

key_events.event: Victoria Island develops as elite residential area
Bridge connects Victoria Island to Lagos Island
Oil boom drives luxury development

eras.landscape: New houses behind compound walls. Bar Beach crowded on weekends. The bridge connecting the island to the city center. The beginnings of Lagos's most exclusive address.

eras.label: Oil Money District
eras.headline: The Business Island
eras.description: The oil boom transformed Victoria Island from a residential neighborhood into Lagos's premier business district. International banks, oil companies, embassies, and five-star hotels clustered on the island. The gleaming towers contrasted sharply with the informality of the rest of Lagos.

key_events.event: Major international corporations establish offices
Victoria Island becomes Lagos's financial center
Hotels and high-end retail follow the banks

eras.landscape: Glass towers rising from the sand. International flags outside embassies. Hotel lobbies with air conditioning cold enough to need a jacket. The most formal, most Western-facing neighborhood in Lagos.

eras.label: Eko Atlantic
eras.headline: Building New Land
eras.description: In 2006, construction began on Eko Atlantic — a new city being built on land reclaimed from the Atlantic Ocean, adjacent to Victoria Island. The project promised to create 10 square kilometers of new real estate, protected by a massive sea wall. It was the most ambitious land reclamation project in Africa.

key_events.event: Eko Atlantic reclamation begins
Great Wall of Lagos sea wall completed
First buildings rise on reclaimed land

eras.landscape: Construction barges pumping sand from the ocean floor. The sea wall taking shape. A new city being built on land that didn't exist a decade ago. The ambition of Lagos in its most literal form.

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Gleaming Shore
eras.description: Victoria Island in 2025 is the face Lagos shows the world — glass towers, international hotels, tech campuses, and Eko Atlantic taking shape offshore. It is the most expensive real estate in West Africa. The contrast with the rest of Lagos is extreme. This is where Nigeria's ambition is most visible.
eras.landscape: The Eko Atlantic skyline rising from reclaimed land. Victoria Island's towers reflecting the lagoon. International restaurants and tech offices. The most expensive square kilometers in Africa, built on sand.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: The New Coast
eras.description: Victoria Island and Eko Atlantic will be on the front line of sea level rise. The sea wall that protects Eko Atlantic will be tested. The question is whether you can build a gleaming new city on the edge of a rising ocean.
eras.landscape: The towers of Eko Atlantic against the Atlantic sky. The sea wall holding. The future of urban ambition on the coast of a warming world.

future_scenarios.label: African Dubai
future_scenarios.description: Eko Atlantic is complete and thriving — a planned city that works. Victoria Island and Eko Atlantic together form the financial capital of Africa. The sea wall holds. The money flows.

future_scenarios.label: The Sea Returns
future_scenarios.description: Rising seas test the sea wall constantly. Maintenance costs are enormous. Some of the reclaimed land has been surrendered back to the ocean. The gleaming city adapts to the reality that the Atlantic has its own plans.

locations.name: Harlem
locations.tagline: The capital of Black America — where the Renaissance proved that art could change a nation.

eras.label: Lenape Land
eras.headline: The Upland
eras.description: Upper Manhattan was Lenape territory — hilly, forested, with streams running to both rivers. The area that would become Harlem was a landscape of old-growth forest, meadows, and freshwater springs. The Lenape hunted deer in these woods and fished in the Harlem River.

key_events.event: Lenape settlements in upper Manhattan
Henry Hudson sails past

eras.landscape: Dense forest on the hills. Streams flowing to the rivers on either side. Meadows in the clearings. The island narrowing to a rocky ridge at its northern end.

eras.label: New Haarlem
eras.headline: The Dutch Farm
eras.description: In 1658, Peter Stuyvesant established the village of Nieuw Haarlem — named after Haarlem in the Netherlands. It was a farming community, connected to New Amsterdam by a rough road. The Dutch settlers grew tobacco and grain. The village was remote and frequently raided.

key_events.event: Nieuw Haarlem established by Dutch settlers
English take over — name becomes Harlem

eras.landscape: A small cluster of Dutch farmhouses. Fields of tobacco and grain. The road to New Amsterdam rough and dangerous. A frontier settlement at the island's northern end.
sources: Russell Shorto, The Island at the Center of the World (2004)

eras.label: Country Estates
eras.headline: Hamilton's Harlem
eras.description: By the late 18th century, Harlem was country estate territory. Alexander Hamilton built The Grange here in 1802. The area was rural, elegant, and connected to downtown Manhattan by stagecoach. Rich New Yorkers built summer homes in Harlem to escape the city's heat and disease.

key_events.event: Harlem is rural countryside — estates and farms
Alexander Hamilton builds The Grange in Harlem
Railroad reaches Harlem — commuting begins

eras.landscape: Country estates with sweeping lawns. The Harlem River visible from the hills. Orchards and gardens. A rural haven that happens to be on Manhattan Island.

eras.label: The Village Grows
eras.headline: Brownstone Harlem
eras.description: After the Civil War, Harlem was developed as an upper-middle-class residential neighborhood. Brownstones and row houses lined the new avenues. The elevated railway connected Harlem to downtown. The neighborhood was built for white middle-class New Yorkers — the transformation that would define Harlem was still decades away.

key_events.event: Harlem developing as middle-class residential neighborhood
Elevated railway reaches Harlem
Brownstone construction boom

eras.landscape: New brownstones lining wide avenues. The elevated train clattering overhead. Tree-lined blocks. A neighborhood built for comfort and respectability.
sources: Gilbert Osofsky, Harlem: The Making of a Ghetto (1966)

eras.label: The Harlem Renaissance
eras.headline: When Harlem Was the World
eras.description: The Harlem Renaissance was the most important cultural flowering in African American history. Between 1920 and 1935, Harlem produced Langston Hughes, Zora Neale Hurston, Duke Ellington, Louis Armstrong, Aaron Douglas, and James Weldon Johnson. The Cotton Club and the Savoy Ballroom drew the world. Harlem proved that Black culture was not marginal — it was essential.

key_events.event: Great Migration brings Black Southerners to Harlem
The New Negro anthology published — Harlem Renaissance at its peak
Langston Hughes publishes 'The Weary Blues'
Harlem riot marks the end of the Renaissance era

eras.landscape: The Cotton Club's neon. The Savoy Ballroom's dance floor. Lenox Avenue on Saturday night — the most alive street in America. Jazz from every doorway. Poetry in every café. The most concentrated cultural explosion of the 20th century.
sources: David Levering Lewis, When Harlem Was in Vogue (1981)

eras.label: After the Dream
eras.headline: The Struggle Continues
eras.description: By the late 1960s, Harlem was scarred by poverty, drugs, and disinvestment. The Renaissance was a memory. MLK had been assassinated. Malcolm X — who had preached on Harlem's streets — had been assassinated three years earlier. But the community endured. The cultural institutions survived. Harlem was down, not out.

key_events.event: Harlem riot after police shooting of teenager
Malcolm X assassinated at the Audubon Ballroom
MLK assassination — Harlem mourns

eras.landscape: Boarded storefronts on 125th Street. The Apollo Theatre still lit. Brownstones deteriorating. The community holding on through decades of disinvestment. The Renaissance architecture still beautiful, even in decline.
sources: Manning Marable, Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention (2011)

eras.label: The Second Renaissance
eras.headline: Harlem Rising Again
eras.description: The 2000s brought investment back to Harlem — and with it, the tensions of gentrification. Brownstones were restored. New restaurants opened. The Apollo Theatre was landmarked. But rents rose and long-time residents were pushed out. Harlem's second renaissance was real but contested.

key_events.event: Bill Clinton opens his post-presidential office on 125th Street
Brownstone restoration boom — gentrification accelerates
Harlem population shift — for the first time, less than 50% Black

eras.landscape: Restored brownstones next to unrenovated ones. New restaurants on Frederick Douglass Boulevard. The Apollo still hosting amateur night. A neighborhood caught between its history and its future.
sources: Michael Henry Adams, Harlem: Lost and Found (2002)

eras.label: Present Day
eras.headline: The Capital Endures
eras.description: Harlem in 2025 is transformed and transforming. The brownstones are gorgeous. The cultural institutions survive. The Apollo still hosts amateur night. But the demographics have shifted dramatically. The question that defines Harlem now: can a neighborhood honor its Black cultural legacy while its Black population declines?
eras.landscape: 125th Street busy with commerce. The Apollo's sign lit. Brownstones restored to their original elegance. New towers rising along the avenues. The cultural capital of Black America, changed but not erased.

eras.label: Futures
eras.headline: What the Capital Becomes
eras.description: Harlem's future is tied to the question of whether cultural identity can survive gentrification. The buildings will endure. The question is what happens inside them.
eras.landscape: The brownstones will still line the avenues. The Apollo will still be on 125th Street. What Harlem means depends on who lives there.

future_scenarios.label: Cultural District
future_scenarios.description: Harlem is designated a cultural heritage district with protections for Black-owned businesses, artist housing, and cultural institutions. The community land trust model preserves affordability. Harlem remains the capital of Black American culture.

future_scenarios.label: Upper Upper Manhattan
future_scenarios.description: Harlem has been fully absorbed into upper Manhattan's luxury real estate market. The Apollo is a museum. The brownstones are worth millions. The cultural heritage is celebrated in plaques and festivals, but the community that created it has dispersed.

locations.name: Alamo
locations.tagline: Rancho San Ramon was a million acres of cattle and oak. The suburb that replaced it is one of the wealthiest communities in California. The hills remember what was here before.

eras.label: Bay Miwok Land
eras.image_query: california oak woodland valley native landscape
eras.headline: The Valley Between the Hills
eras.description: The San Ramon Valley — the broad inland valley between the Diablo Range to the east and the hills above Oakland to the west — was Bay Miwok territory, its communities living in the oak woodland and grassland that covered the valley floor and hillsides. The area around present-day Alamo was prime Bay Miwok habitat: the valley's reliable freshwater creeks, the dense stands of valley oak producing abundant acorns, the grasslands full of elk and pronghorn, and the mild inland climate that made year-round occupation comfortable. The Bay Miwok maintained permanent villages near reliable water sources, moving seasonally to gather food across a territory that extended from the bay to the inland valleys. Mount Diablo — visible from every part of the San Ramon Valley — was a sacred mountain, its summit used for ceremony and navigation across the region.

key_events.event: Bay Miwok establish permanent villages along San Ramon Creek and its tributaries
San Ramon Valley supports a thriving Bay Miwok population estimated in the thousands
Pedro Fages expedition crosses the valley — first Europeans to enter the San Ramon Valley
Mission San Francisco de Asís established — Bay Miwok begin to be drawn into the mission system

eras.landscape: The valley floor a mosaic of native bunchgrass and wildflower meadow, the creek corridors lined with sycamore, willow, and cottonwood. Valley oaks massive and ancient on the hillsides, their canopy shading the deer trails below. Mount Diablo to the east, its summit often visible above the hills. The air dry and warm in summer, the hills green after the winter rains. Tule elk moving through the grassland in herds.
sources: Richard Levy, Bay Miwok in Handbook of North American Indians (1978)
Contra Costa County Historical Society, San Ramon Valley history
Alan Leventhal, Bay Miwok cultural geography research

eras.label: Rancho San Ramon
eras.image_query: california golden hills cattle rancho historical landscape
eras.headline: A Million Acres of Cattle
eras.description: In 1834, the Mexican government granted Rancho San Ramon — a vast land grant covering most of the San Ramon Valley — to Dolores Pacheco and later to Jose Maria Amador, a former soldier and mission mayordomo who became one of the most powerful rancheros in California. Amador's rancho was a cattle operation of enormous scale, its land stretching from the hills above Oakland across the entire valley to the slopes of Mount Diablo. The rancho economy was built on hide and tallow — cattle hides sold to Boston trading ships that became the basis for the leather goods trade, and rendered tallow for candles and soap. Richard Henry Dana's 'Two Years Before the Mast,' written in 1840, describes the California hide trade that made ranchos like San Ramon wealthy. The valley's creek-fed grasslands were ideal for the vast herds that rancho production required.

key_events.event: Rancho San Ramon granted — one of the largest land grants in the Bay Area
Jose Maria Amador operates the rancho — cattle herds numbering in the thousands
Richard Henry Dana's 'Two Years Before the Mast' describes the California hide trade
Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo — California transferred to the United States

eras.landscape: The valley transformed by rancho cattle — the native bunchgrass grazed down and replaced by European annual grasses that would permanently change the valley's ecology.
